HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "MATTHEW BARNEY: THE CREMASTER CYCLE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through June 11). The most anticipated show by any American artist to emerge in a decade or more. "Cremaster," Mr. Barney's nine-year, five-film project, here presented whole for the first time, is an inspired benchmark of ambition, scope and forthright provocation for art in the new century. I recall Elizabeth Murray's describing how Philip Guston's crazy late works gave her heart to do her own mature paintings. Mr. Barney has brought to the art world a new freedom to explore narrative. He has introduced a new repertory of materials, gooey, strange, malleable and synthetic, which nobody thought of as germane before. Never mind that the films and many (not all) of his related sculptures, installations and photographs are very beautiful. The show, an installation itself, brings them together. The earliest "Cremaster" sculptures are film props, cobbled into installations that don't jell. But the latest are better: twin steel towers framed in plastic, a suite of abstract sculptures derived from automobile chassis. Vaseline and plastic combine with cement and steel -- pink and gray, rough and smooth, hard and soft -- the materials sustaining a narrative of formal eloquence. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $15; $10 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "THE KIDS ARE ALRIGHT: PHOTOGRAPHS BY RYAN McGINLEY," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through May 18). It isn't often that an artist makes his New York solo exhibition debut in the august galleries of the Whitney. But Mr. McGinley, 26, is doing so as part of the museum's "First Exposure" series, a showcase for new photography. He works in what might be described as a life-style genre, whose exemplars also include Nan Goldin, Wolfgang Tillmans and Larry Clark. The 20 large color pictures of Mr. McGinley's 20-something friends, lovers and fellow artists avoid the grit of Mr. Clark's work and the noirish narcissicism of Ms. Goldin's. Instead, these are basically sunny, feel-good pictures, particularly interesting for an approach to sexuality that suggests intriguing socio-political shifts in gay self-presentation. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter).

* "MANET/VELAZQUEZ: THE FRENCH TASTE FOR SPANISH PAINTING," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through June 8). The Met has clearly called in every chip to make this show spectacular. The first rooms are a virtual survey of great Spanish painting of the 17th and 18th centuries; then comes a virtual Manet retrospective, with some Degas and Courbet for good measure; then a virtual 19th-century American overview of the most gifted portraitists influenced by Spanish painting via Manet, Degas and Courbet: Eakins, Chase, Sargent and Whistler. The thesis of Spanish influence on French art is hardly new, but it is explored in such precise and fresh detail, discreetly, without pushing comparisons (in that respect it's not like "Matisse Picasso" at the Modern, notwithstanding the coincidental titled pairings) that you would be churlIsh not to leave edified and amazed. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

"MATERIAL DIFFERENCES: ART AND IDENTITY IN AFRICA," Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through Aug. 15). Part Art Methods 101, part Advanced Connoisseurship, this handsome, thoughtful show examines the potent connection between matter and meaning in diverse African cultures and shows them to be organically connected. The material is spiritual in these cultures, and the show's 130 mostly ceremonial objects, arranged strictly according to materials and techniques, reflect the power of that belief. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

* "MATISSE PICASSO," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 4520 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through May 19). If you're thinking of skipping it because of the crowds, that's not a good enough excuse. This is one for the ages: an eye-educating, often revelatory parlor game, with the fate of modern art as the stakes. The premise is a little dubious -- the two of them competing as if in stately isolation from everything else going on in art -- but the results look great. Choosing a winner is the sport of the event and the inevitable outcome of pitting titans mano a mano. Matisse comes out looking consistently good. To grasp 20th-century art, Picasso once said, "you ought to see side by side everything Matisse and I were doing." He was right about that. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; to 9 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays. Admission: $20; $15.50 for students and 65+; under 16 with an adult, free. Reserved tickets: Ticketmaster, (212) 307-5577; or toll free, (866) 879-6662, with Ticketmaster surcharges (Kimmelman).

"ELIE NADELMAN: SCULPTOR OF MODERN LIFE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through July 20). Despite the clarion title, this exhibition is too monotonous, stiffly installed and short on drawings to do full justice to the erudite, polymorphous achievement of the Polish-born American sculptor Elie Nadelman (1882-1946). Still, don't miss this opportunity to see his work in quantity, especially the streamlined wood figures from the 1920's and the small truculent plaster figurines, which were found in his studio after his death. Their suave economy, ineffable stillness, delicate gestures and seamless blend of historical and popular sources make them among the most complex, fully visual sculptures in Western art. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

* "ST. ADOLF-GIANT-CREATION: THE ART OF ADOLF WOLFLI," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through May 18). The distinction between insider and outsider art is all but nullified by this stunning show of the densely patterned drawings that Wolfli (1864-1930) made in the last 35 years of his life at Waldau, a mental asylum in Bern, Switzerland. Brought to order by vast architectonic structures that allow several forms of communication to speak at once yet remain distinct, these works are embedded with saints, devils, written texts, mathematical calculations, musical scores and geometric symbols. They treat the eye to a ride through a multicultural terrain bounded by Piranesi, biblical myth, illuminated manuscripts, tantric mandalas and Swiss cuckoo clocks. And they attest to a vision as ancient as it is modern that verifies both Wolfli's careful observation of his surroundings and Jung's theory of the collective unconscious. Not to be missed. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $9; $5, students and 62+ (Smith).

* "THOMAS STRUTH, 1977-2002," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through May 18). This midcareer retrospective is the right event for right now: serious, tradition bound, circumspect about the world. Mr. Struth operates from a chilly peak, where the air is thin. But what results are obsessively meticulous photographs, some of them enormous, like mural paintings. They are hypnotic, silent, slightly claustrophobic, brainy and gorgeous, qualities that can seem in lively tension with one another. Art is a means of "locating yourself in your time," Mr. Struth has said. He has done series of streets, jungles, museums, portraits and church facades. Standing before his crowded museums and churches, we can become absorbed in the chaos of culture, sacred places made profane. In the jungle we acquiesce to the spiritual pleasure of solitude. The silence is calming. We may find ourselves in our time.Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

* "WHISTLER, WOMEN AND FASHION," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through July 13). A dandy, a wit and a social butterfly who cultivated his image as a star aesthete, James McNeill Whistler (1834-1903) had a lifelong interest in fashion and women's clothes. This show honors the centenary of the painter's death by exploring his intense, unabashed involvement with fashion. He obsessed over what his female sitters wore, choosing the clothes they posed in and in some cases actually designing them himself. The display includes many major images of women in their finery and several magnificent gowns of the Whistler period along with smaller oils, drawings, pastel studies, costume designs, prints and watercolors, and relevant 19th-century fashion plates. It's a fitting tribute to a bravura brush. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Grace Glueck).

Galleries: Uptown

JANNIS KOUNELLIS, Michael Werner, 4 East 77th Street, (212) 988-1623 (through May 24). These works on paper from the 1970's and 80's by Mr. Kounellis, a maverick sculptor and painter who participated in the Arte Povera movement in the 1960's, tap into the many themes of his larger projects. They range from the merest of sketches to finished drawings. Fragile wisps of thought, more substantial images like factories and locomotives, black overall patterns of skull-faces that seem to evoke a mass catastrophe: some fragments are powerful bits of visual poetry, but others are slight to the point of meaninglessness (Glueck).

"SALLY MICHEL, MILTON AVERY: A PORTRAIT," Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through May 30). Also known as Mrs. Milton Avery, the widow of the artist, Sally Michel used her own name as a painter in her own right. This warm memorial tribute to Michel and Avery mounts a group of informal, private portraits of each artist done by the other. A wall of Avery by Michel, who died in January, shows him painting, napping, smoking, reading, thinking, leaning. A facing wall of portraits by Avery (1885-1965) shows Michel smiling, mothering their daughter, March, wearing a new hat and painting a portrait of her husband. This small show is an engaging celebration of a highly productive relationship (Glueck).

"OBSESSIVE PLEASURES," Pavel Zoubok, 1014 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 879-5858 (through May 24). More cheerfully overwrought than obsessive, the works in this theme show include Thomas Lanigan-Schmidt's circular collages of foil, plastic and colored pipe cleaners; Barbara Takenaga's cosmic dot paintings; Daniel Zeller's finely lined drawings, like zany topographical maps; Amy Yoes's paintings of ruffles, stripes, blossoms and architectural elements; John Digby's cut-out vines; Nora Aslan's extremely dense yet expansive flower collages; Aric Obrosey's laceworks; and Christopher Tanner's glittery paisley patterns (Ken Johnson).

* "KURT SCHWITTERS: COLLAGES, PAINTINGS, DRAWINGS, OBJECTS, EPHEMERA," Ubu Gallery, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444 (through May 23). The German artist Kurt Schwitters (1887-1948) made artful arrangements of found scraps -- torn photographs, ticket stubs, labels, newspaper clips and other discarded bits -- into abstract compositions that balanced colors, forms, textures and printed matter to dazzling effect. More than 60 of his works, Dada-oriented but also much influenced by Constructivism and Russian Suprematism, are brought together here in a museum-quality display that ranges in date from before 1920 to the late 1940's. One standout in this bountiful show is a gem from 1931, "Untitled (Red, Gray, Black)," a rigorously structured composition with all the elegant trappings of Suprematism-Constructivism brilliantly translated into "Merz," Schwitters's no-meaning name for his own visual language (Glueck).

GEORGE SEGAL, "Bronze," Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 744-7400 (through June 14). There was always a Hopperesque ennui about Segal's plaster-cast figures. Late works cast in bronze are truly lugubrious. A quartet of chunky women in balletic poses perform a ponderous dance; three dark gray people with the closed eyes of sleepwalkers meet under one-way street signs pointing in two directions; and in "Street Crossing," seven blind souls painted white wander aimlessly in a modern purgatory (Johnson).

HELEN TORR, "Out of the Shadows," James Graham, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through June 8). Torr, the wife of Arthur Dove, was an accomplished if not highly original painter and an excellent draftsman in her own right. This retrospective, organized by Anne Cohen De Pietro of the Heckscher Museum on Long Island, is studded by gems in a range of styles, from ecstatic Dove-esque abstractions to delicate yet sumptuous still lifes that Georgia O'Keeffe might have envied (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

* WILLIAM BECKMAN, Forum, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 355-4545 (through May 17). Mr. Beckman paints like Hans Holbein but in a contemporary mood of existential anxiety. An extraordinarily vivid painting of the artist and his female companion in overcoats, looming bigger than life and gazing out at us with tense, somber expressions, has a novelistic weight to it. They could be characters in a Russell Banks tale, enduring the spiritually and materially erosive demands of modern living (Johnson).

FERNANDA BRUNET, "Bang," Ramis Barquet, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-9090 (through May 16). Graphic pop and gestural dynamism combine in this Mexico City artist's paintings. Ms. Brunet takes images of explosions, deluges, volcanic eruptions and tidal waves from Japanese comic books and turns them into semiabstract compositions, in a palette of earth tones and silver. They humorously suggest transports of erotic ecstasy (Johnson).

JOHN CEDERQUIST, "Furniture That Builds Itself," Franklin Parrasch, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 246-5360 (through May 31). Mr. Cederquist's beautifully made woodworks are simultaneously functional pieces of furniture and zany cartoons in two and three dimensions. With painted Mickey Mouse arms wielding drills and planes as if in the act of building, these funky sculptures are deceptively whimsical meditations on the mind's construction of reality (Johnson).

"HEAVEN AND HELL," Barbara Mathes Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-5135, (through June 6). This high-low meditation includes Stephen Balkenhol's rough, wooden Everyman twins as an angel and a devil; a leering antique silver Satan photographed by Robert Mapplethorpe; montages illustrating Dante's "Inferno" by Robert Rauschenberg; a big celestial photograph by Thomas Ruff; a terrestrial paradise photographed by Thomas Struth; painful signs by Jenny Holzer; and the convergence of an angel and a manhole cover in a luminous nocturne by Joseph Cornell (Johnson).

TOM WESSELMANN, "The Great American 60's," Maxwell Davidson, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 759-7555 (through June 13); "Nudes and Abstracts," Robert Miller, 524 West 26th Street, (212) 366-4774 (through tomorrow). Wesselmann then and now: Davidson's selection of works from the 1960's includes one of the Pop Art master's classic Great American Nude apartment paintings -- real telephone and radiator included -- and seductive small studies of female body parts: pillowy lips, nubile breasts and coy painted toes. The new work at Miller finds the artist in a Matissean mood, folding his pin-up iconography into compositions of Cubist semiabstraction and, with a series of large reliefs of sweeping, brightly colored planes, breaking into purely decorative abstraction (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

OLIVE AYHENS, "Bridges," Gary Tatintsian, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 633-0110 (through May 24). It is hard to capture the dizzying dynamism of New York City in painting, but Ms. Ayhens succeeds with her exuberantly expressionistic canvases. She paints overhead views of streets and bridges with reckless confidence, insouciant disregard for ordinary perspective and a fine eye for detail and light. In some cases she creates shotgun weddings of urban and wilderness scenery with environmentalist intentions, but mainly to vertiginous effect (Johnson).

* ATUL DODIYA, "Broken Branches," BosePacia Modern, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 989-7074 (through May 31). The centerpiece of Mr. Dodiya's haunting New York solo debut show is an installation of nine tall glass-fronted wooden cabinets filled with well-worn objects, including old photographs, tools and handmade prosthetic limbs. The cabinets are copies of those found in a museum at Gandhi's birthplace, and the meticulously composed still lifes inside are political and personal portraits of the texture of India itself, a nation rich in social and spiritual resources but crippled by sectarian hatred. The show also includes a series of beautiful large-scale watercolors, which draw connections between India, where Mr. Dodiya lives, and the larger world (Cotter).

RAINER GROSS, "Doppelganger/Contact Paintings," Axel Raben, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 647-9064 (through May 24). This New York-based German artist makes sensuous abstract paintings by a process of his own invention that involves fusing two paintings face to face and then pulling them apart. Exhibited singly or as diptychs, the paintings look like flaking wall sections. They have lush, supersaturated colors and dry, crusty surfaces that look like velvet from a distance (Johnson).

MAIRA KALMAN, "Just Looking," Julie Saul, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-2410 (through June 14). Ms. Kalman's sweet, sometimes mildly acerbic gouache paintings suggest Alice Neel under the influence of Indian miniature painting. Working on paper with a fine brush and cheerful colors, the prolific children's book illustrator and New Yorker cover artist (co-creator of the "Newyorkistan" map) paints goofy people in parks, portraits of famous designers' dogs and a green plastic pail captioned "Dear Bucket" (Johnson).

"KARAOKE DEATH MACHINE," Daniel Reich, 308 West 21st Street, (917) 408-9097 (through June 2). This is more like a visit to someone's tiny, dark and incredibly cluttered apartment than to a gallery exhibition; actually it is Mr. Reich's tiny, dark and incredibly cluttered apartment-cum-gallery. A stream-of-consciousness salon-style installation of more than 100 small works by more than two dozen artists as well as many images lifted directly from commercial media, the show is uneven, to say the least. But it has a grainy video copy of an early film by Niki de Saint Phalle and an excellent title (Johnson).

JEAN-FRANCOIS MORICEAU AND PETRA MRZYK, "Only for Your Eyes," Marcus Ritter, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 463-7375 (through May 17). This young cartoon-making team generates sight gags with seemingly effortless abandon. Hairy prehistoric people shaving their private parts; anthropomorphic paintings on strike, carrying signs that say, "We want a new curator"; an owl with Mickey Mouse ears; a woman with square breasts; a giant eye with two pupils. More than 100 of these black-ink line drawings, individually framed and stacked up against the wall, will give your sense of humor an invigorating workout (Johnson).

BRUCE MOROZKO, John Elder, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 462-2600 (through May 24). A former designer for Jim Henson Associates and a teacher of monster-making classes in public schools, Mr. Morozko makes whimsical clay sculpture featuring regiments of doglike creatures that march in order, organize in stacks and turn themselves inside out. "Gene Pool" is the touching portrait of a racially mixed nuclear family: a gourd-headed mother, block-headed father and their two rubbery children (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* "THE STAGE OF DRAWING: GESTURE AND ACT," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through May 31). It's not easy to assemble a truly engaging show from a vast collection of drawings like that owned by the Tate in Britain. But this one, selected by a British artist, Avis Newman, with Catherine de Zegher, director of the Drawing Center, really works. Not a tiresome institutional tour but a vividly personal one, it views drawing as "an open-ended and exploratory activity," with exhibits ranging from a 295-foot line on a roll of wrapped paper to precise renderings of 19th-century hairdos. The mix of artists runs from J. M. W. Turner to Andy Warhol; the juxtapositions reveal affinities across centuries and cultures (Glueck).

Brooklyn

ROBERT GRUNDER, Sixtyseven, 67 Metropolitan Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 486-0387 (through May 18). Mr. Grunder's semiabstract paintings of mall stores and parking lots are O.K., but his bird's-eye views of freeways, overpasses and cloverleaf intersections painted on white grounds have a cool dynamism that nicely evokes the speediness of modern life (Johnson).

Last Chance

* "MONTIEN BOONMA: THE TEMPLE OF THE MIND," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 517-2742 (through Sunday). The art of the Thai artist Montien Boonma (1953-2000) combines many influences, from Southeast Asian Buddhism to Arte Povera and Joseph Beuys. But his art, by turns witty and somber, is not primarily about hybrid identities; it is about how to forge a life of psychic balance in an unbalanced and unbalancing world. There's nobody like him and nothing in town like this modestly scaled survey show. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

"FRAKTUR TREASURES FROM THE SCHWENKFELDER LIBRARY AND HERITAGE CENTER," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through Sunday). Among the more vibrant practitioners of fraktur, the Pennsylvania German art of embellishing letters and documents, were members of a Protestant sect called the Schwenkfelders, still going strong in Pennsylvania, where they migrated in the early 18th century. They brought with them the old-country custom of illuminating documents with decorative writing, drawings, borders, angels, hearts, flowers, birds and more esoteric symbols. The highly stylized work was called fraktur from the broken elements of the lettering. The Schwenkfelders put their all into Geburtscheine (birth certificates), Vorschriften (writing samplers), love letters, marriage certificates, religious texts and house blessings. The work in this show, both religious and secular, is lent by the Schwenkfelder Library in Pennsburg, Pa., which since 1884 has collected more than 1,000 examples of Pennsylvania fraktur and is especially rich in Schwenkfeldiana. Don't let all the cutesy hearts and flowers put you off; there's an innocent exuberance about this work that's captivating. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

JOHN WILLIAM HILL, Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through tomorrow). Hill (1812-1879) founded the now little remembered American Pre-Raphaelite movement. He was immune to the medievalism of the English Pre-Raphaelites, but he took to heart John Ruskin's admonition to work from nature. Most of the skillfully made drawings and watercolors here are conventionally picturesque, but two densely worked watercolors of fruits, vegetables and nuts on the ground have an earthy palpability that one imagines Henry David Thoreau would have appreciated (Johnson).

TAKASHI MURAKAMI, Marianne Boesky, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 680-9889 (through tomorrow). Mr. Murakami, the self-styled Warhol of Japan, has entered into a contract with Louis Vuitton to design handbags and other merchandise and to update the company's logo. Whether you find this appalling or intriguing, paintings rendering the distinctive Vuitton pattern in confectionery colors are visually ravishing, and a video cartoon of a little girl plunging into a Vuitton-patterned dream world is entrancing (Johnson).

LAWSON OYEKAN, "Trial With Light," Garth Clark, 45-46 21st Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 706-2491 (through tomorrow). This London sculptor's upbringing in Nigeria is reflected in impressive six- to seven-foot totem-like works in red clay, which evoke African tribal art and giant African termite mounds. But they are also canny plays on Modernist precedents: the monolithic bulbous forms evoke Minimalism and the perforated, mud-pie construction calls to mind Process Art. All of which makes a compelling mix of the modern, the timeless, the local and the cosmic (Johnson).

"POETRY OF SIGHT: THE PRINTS OF JAMES McNEILL WHISTLER (1834-1903)," New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089 (through tomorrow). A salute on the centenary of his death to the painter's brilliance as a printmaker, this show presents more than 130 etchings, drypoints and lithographs that trace Whistler's career from its beginnings in Paris to his last years. A much less showy and theatrical side of Whistler is apparent in this display, which includes the famous sets done in France, London and Venice. Other graphic work, correspondence, photographs and personal documents are also on view in this well-organized presentation. Hours: Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free (Glueck).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Whistler's "Harmony in Pink and Gray" at the Frick Collection. (The Frick Collection, New York); Detail from "Basket of Vegetables" by Helen Torr in the "Out of the Shadows" exhibition at the James Graham gallery on Madison Avenue. (Museum of Modern Art, New York)

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
Free Air Or Not, Your Tires Need It

BYLINE:  By PHIL PATTON 

 BODY:
THE question from my daughter, a new driver, came one cold rainy evening. "Where do I go to get air for my tires?" she asked. I had to confess to that parental rarity: no answer. The gas station I most often used in our New Jersey town had recently removed its air pump. Another pump I knew of was broken.
 Her concern made me realize that it had been a long time since I had checked the air in my own tires. (Or cleaned my gutters, waterproofed my boots, defrosted my refrigerator or any of the other tasks that fall into the same category of tedious responsibility.) Soft tires can lead to flats and accidents, and they reduce fuel economy, but many of us fail to tend to them. An estimated one-third of vehicles on the road have at least one soft tire. 
 It used to be easier to attend to one's pneumatic responsibilities. When attendants routinely wiped windshields and offered to check oil levels, gas stations all had free air pumps.
Now, you may not find a working air pump at all. The modern concept of a gas station is less car-servicing business and more convenience store with gas pump. Air for customers' tires isn't much of a concern.
A study released by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in November 2001 showed that while 90 percent of gas stations had air pumps, 10 percent of them didn't work, and of those that did, nearly a third provided inaccurate pressure readings. If you do find one working, you are likely to have to pay to use it.
My daughter and I spent that evening driving around in a cold drizzle looking for a pump. I asked her if she had quarters.
"How much air do you get for a quarter?" she asked.
"Just about enough to fill three tires," I answered, speaking from experience.
"How much for 50 cents?"
"The same."
But in the end we had a stroke of luck. In Clifton, N.J., at the E&A Gulf station, we actually found a free pump.
"The station up the road charges 50 cents for air," I teased the attendant. "Is their air better than your air?"
"Free air is good," he said. "People like free air."
"Free air" -- a slogan once displayed at gas station tire pumps -- symbolized the freedom of the road in the early days of auto travel, when flat tires were almost daily events. Now, using an air pump usually costs a quarter or 50 cents for five minutes.
While air for tires may no longer be free, it's still a bargain. A 20 percent underinflation in a car's tires can increase fuel consumption by 10 percent, according to Bill Egan, a Goodyear engineer. The highway safety agency and the Department of Energy have calculated that underinflated tires increase gas consumption in this country by 3.4 million gallons a day, or 1.24 billion a year. Calculating the cost of gasoline at about $1.60 a gallon, that's nearly $2 billion.
Underinflation also causes flats. The Society of Automotive Engineers has reported that 87 percent of flat tires have a history of underinflation.
And soft tires can also lead to handling problems, especially on trucks and S.U.V.'s. Studies released by the highway safety agency and the University of Pittsburgh School of Engineering suggest that about a quarter of cars and a third of S.U.V.'s and light trucks are operating with at least one tire that is 20 percent below ideal pressure.
Basic tire care is simple. Find the suggested pressure numbers inside the door frame or in the owner's manual. (Don't go by the figure stamped on the tire; it is the maximum pressure for the tire itself but may not be right for your particular car.) Then use a gauge to check the tires. The familiar tire gauge, about the size of a fat pen, costs about $5; digital models run to $20 or so. Tires should be checked when cool or at least after a relatively short drive. And don't forget to check the spare.
Few drivers check their tire inflation pressure monthly, as recommended. (The American Rubber Manufacturers Association says the proportion is 11 percent).
After the Firestone tire recall of 2000, Congress passed a law requiring that vehicles have signals on the instrument panel to alert drivers to low tire pressure, but it doesn't take effect until 2006. So far, the systems that might be used to accomplish this remain technically quirky.
For decades, a gas-station air pump was usually an Air Tower, made by the Eco Company, which is now part of OPW, a maker of pumps based in Cincinnati. To use it, you simply turn a dial to the desired inflation pressure number and hold the hose to the tire until the machine chimes three times. "The Air Tower is reliable, field-proven and time-tested," said Gary Specht, customer service manager for OPW, but though the company still makes it, it has fallen out of favor because it is comparatively expensive to build and maintain.
Now, motorists will often encounter pumps made by Air Serv of Mendota Heights, Minn., sometimes combined with vacuum cleaners. Some are free, others take coins. Probably the most common is a model with a retractable hose to guard against vandalism. 
If you miss the old days, you can buy a restored classic pump from Vintage Vending in Salem, N.H., which specializes in restored Coca-Cola machines, gasoline pumps and the like. The company will sell a restored vintage Air Tower for $1,995.

GRAPHIC: Photo: AIR CHECK -- Underinflated tires can lead to flats and higher gas consumption. But still most motorists don't pay attention. (Christopher E. Jones/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2941 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
Cabaret, the Champagne of New York

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
On a cold, rainy Friday in April, Feinstein's at the Regency, the 140-seat cabaret in the Regency Hotel that metamorphoses from a corporate breakfast nook in the mornings to a supper club at night, was packed with patrons who had paid a $60 cover charge to attend an extraordinary show that might never be seen again after its two-week run.
 Holding forth at one of two pianos was the composer Michel Legrand. Sitting on a stool nearby was his longtime collaborator, Alan Bergman (half of the Hollywood husband-and-wife lyric-writing team of Alan and Marilyn Bergman). Facing Mr. Legrand on the second piano was the jazz whiz Mike Renzi. Midway through the show, the pop-jazz singer Patti Austin, who had the first hit recording (a duet with James Ingram) of the Legrand-Bergman standard "How Do You Keep the Music Playing?," arrived onstage and opened with another of the team's finest songs, "You Must Believe in Spring." 
 As the musicians whirled through a cavalcade of Legrand-Bergman chestnuts, from "The Windmills of Your Mind" to the high points of the score for "Yentl," they offered a deeply personal retrospective of one of the most extravagantly romantic songwriting legacies of the last three decades. Vocally Mr. Legrand was as exuberant as a teenager, while Mr. Bergman projected a gentle, sagelike wistfulness. Delivering the stentorian ballads from "Yentl," Ms. Austin exuded a perfect mixture of poise and grandeur. All the while Mr. Legrand and Mr. Renzi riffed together on their dual pianos like two jazzy Rachmaninoffs.
The evening's blend of intimacy and musicianship represented the essence of the cabaret experience at its best, and the show was the highlight of a New York nightclub season that has only another month and a half left. (Still to come are Mary Cleere Haran at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel and the Pizzarelli Family at Feinstein's, both top-notch.) Each year, there may be 10 shows of comparable quality in New York's upscale supper clubs.
And such evenings don't come cheap; dinner for two and a show at Feinstein's, at the 100-seat Cafe Carlyle in the Carlyle Hotel or at the 85-seat Oak Room can easily cost more than $250. Still, that's not quite as much as the price of a restaurant dinner and two orchestra seats for a hit Broadway musical. And in terms of bang for the buck, a great cabaret performance provides a more transporting emotional experience than a brassy Broadway musical.
This weekend, two premier cabaret acts are appearing at the Cafe Carlyle and the Oak Room. At the Carlyle, Bobby Short, the ebullient 78-year-old singer and pianist who turns every performance into a party, began his 35th spring season on Tuesday, performing with an eight-member jazz band. If Mr. Short's voice has grown noticeably hoarser in recent years, he remains a great entertainer who projects the spirited joie de vivre of a sophisticated cherub, performing a repertory that features the best songs by the likes of Cole Porter, Duke Ellington, Billy Strayhorn, Andy Razaf, Cy Coleman and Vernon Duke. At the Algonquin, Karen Akers, a statuesque beauty with a rich, buzzing contralto, is performing "Theater Songs," a program of beautifully chosen out-of-the-way gems from Broadway musicals (some of them obscure), with the pianist Don Rebic. In the two decades she has been performing, Ms. Akers has undergone a personal revolution, thawing from a regal, diffident ice princess into an intensely expressive and communicative performer who has found a rare balance between Broadway extroversion and an art singer's refinement. 
Over at Feinstein's, Keely Smith, the 75-year-old singer and widow of Louis Prima, is keeping the flame alive for raucous Las Vegas swing with a tribute to Count Basie, accompanied by a hot nine-piece band that exuberantly mimics the Basie style. With Prima, Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis Jr. and Dean Martin now gone, Ms. Smith, who used to play a deadpan Cher-like foil to her husband's Sonny-like cutup, is the closest we'll get to witnessing first-hand an offhand style of Rat Pack playfulness that has become legendary.
Because the cabaret experience has so much to do with the intimate sharing of emotional experience through song, the older a performer gets, the richer that communication tends to be. Even whenthe voice begins to fail, the seams and cracks can work to a singer's expressive advantage by infusing a song lyric with a more profound sense of time. The cabaret genre is responsible for making popular a raft of modern standards, led by the theater songs of Stephen Sondheim, and the brilliant, cynical jazz commentaries of Dave Frishberg. Now and then, an isolated gem like Francesca Blumenthal's "Lies of Handsome Men" or Jason Robert Brown's "Stars and the Moon" becomes a standard within the genre.
Nobody embodies the agelessness of popular song more evocatively than Blossom Dearie, the pixielike singer and jazz pianist who is performing at Danny's Skylight Room. (The small, sparely appointed cabaret in the back of Danny's Sea Palace, a Thai restaurant on Restaurant Row, is the most discriminating of Manhattan's second-tier cabarets.)
With her pageboy haircut and tart wisp of a voice, Ms. Dearie, who is in her late 70's, finds several layers of wit, wistfulness -- and yes, sex! -- in a repertory that runs from Dave Frishberg to Antonio Carlos Jobim. (Her dreamy rendition of Jobim's "Wave," on her recent album, "Blossom's Planet," is definitive.)

'You Do It for Love'
The term "fabulous invalid," which has regularly been affixed to the theater, might more aptly be applied to cabaret, since its economic survival is always in question. A series of interviews with booking agents and club owners suggest that business is down overall about 10 percent in New York City since 9/11 in a field where profits are marginal at best. Or as one club owner put it: "Nobody makes money in the nightclub business. You do it for love." Whether the top-of-the-line cabarets associated with hotels make money is a matter of debate. But the nightclubs' name value and the prestige (and the hotel business they might attract) are ultimately incalculable.
In the last year, three Manhattan cabarets have closed. Arci's Place, the popular and well-run supper club at Park Avenue South and 31st Street, where Christine Ebersole brought a brilliant act that rivaled the glory days of Bette Midler in fun and musicality, closed after a real estate dispute and has been looking for a new home. Judy's, a lower-echelon showcase club in Chelsea, also closed, as did a short-lived upstairs supper club atop the Firebird restaurant on Restaurant Row.

A Surge of Youth
Although the cabaret field has the image of a high-class retreat for fading older performers, young blood is stirring up the field. Peter Cincotti, the gifted singer, pianist and songwriter whose debut album recently supplanted albums by Diana Krall and Tony Bennett and K. D. Lang on Billboard's chart of best-selling jazz albums, is a 19-year-old student at Columbia College who can play like Fats Waller and Erroll Garner and sing like the young Jack Jones. The rapid rise of this earnest and meticulous performer follows that of Ms. Krall, now a platinum-selling artist, who made several appearances at the Oak Room, and of the charismatic New Orleans singer and pianist Harry Connick Jr., whose blazing ascent into all-around show business stardom took him briefly through the Oak Room.
Michael Feinstein, part owner of Feinstein's at the Regency and its new sister club, Feinstein's at the Cinegrill in Los Angeles, was only 29 when he made his New York debut at the Oak Room in the mid-1980's. Since then, he has become a major concert and nightclub attraction who sells out his annual engagements at the Regency. Along with Mr. Short, Barbara Cook (who has graduated to concerts) and a few others, he is one of aselect group of cabaret performers who make serious money performing popular standards.

Breaking Through
For most of the second-level performers, the cabaret life is a grueling struggle with modest expectations. One of the few who have broken through is Ann Hampton Callaway, the honey-voiced singer who appeared on Broadway in "Swing" and moved increasingly from pop standards into jazz. A skillful songwriter, who made her name in piano bars improvising songs from audience suggestions, Ms. Callaway is performing at the Kaplan Penthouse tonight and tomorrow as part of Lincoln Center's American Songbook series. Another is KT Sullivan, a comic raconteur with operatic training, who is appearing at the Neue Galerie on the Upper East Side.
Both women have played the Oak Room, which has also boosted the career of Stacy Kent, a young, lemony-voiced American-born jazz singer and Sarah Lawrence College graduate who built a following in England before tackling the United States. To hear her tangy duets with her husband and musical partner, the saxophonist Jim Tomlinson, is to hear echoes of interplay between Billie Holiday and Lester Young, or Astrud Gilberto and Stan Getz, but with a delicious dash of screwball humor thrown in.
Jane Monheit, a plummy-voiced pop-jazz singer in her early 20's, has also established a successful career bouncing between jazz clubs like the Blue Note and cabarets like the Oak Room and the Cafe Carlyle. If Ms. Monheit has little to say onstage, she has a ravishing voice to match her sultry, sensual air and has built a solid following. For unalloyed lyricism, her versions of "Some Other Time" and "Haunted Heart" on her newest album, "In the Sun" (N-Coded Music), are hard to beat.
Another talented young contender is the Canadian singer Michael Buble, the protege of the pop producer David Foster, who nurtured the career of Josh Groban. "Michael Buble" (143 Records/Reprise), the debut album of the singer, who recently played the Cinegrill in Los Angeles and is soon to open at the Blue Note in New York, is benefiting from a major record label push. Like many younger cabaret singers, he freely mixes rock-era songs with pre-rock standards, and the material runs from "The Way You Look Tonight" to the Bee Gees ("How Can You Mend a Broken Heart?") to Queen's rockabilly knockoff, "Crazy Little Thing Called Love," to the old Dean Martin hit "Sway," which coincidentally appears on Mr. Cincotti's record.

Mixing the Categories
No one has given traditional pop music a bigger shot in the arm lately than Norah Jones, the genre-bending young singer, pianist and songwriter whose six million-selling album, "Come Away With Me" (Blue Note), recently won her several Grammys. Ms. Jones didn't ascend through more staid uptown clubs but first gained a local following downtown at the Living Room. She later played Makor on the Upper West Side and Joe's Pub in the East Village.
Like most of the younger singers, Ms. Jones doesn't draw the kinds of stylistic and temporal distinctions -- between soft-rock and Tin Pan Alley, between country, pop and rock -- that the older generation of singers has done. Her shows freely mix material by Willie Nelson and Hank Williams with traditional standards like "The Nearness of You" and originals like "Come Away With Me," the sweetly sexy and uncategorizable title cut of her album.
Her success and the surprise success of Rod Stewart's "It Had to Be You" (J Records), a mediocre album of standards, all done in variations of the same loping tempo, are cited by champions of traditional pop as evidence that a widespread hunger for that music exists. But since mass-market radio, which is still the engine behind record company promotion, for the most part turns a deaf ear to traditional pop, most of the best of that music goes undiscovered. Satellite radio and adult-alternative formats, however, have begun making some tentative inroads into the top-40 mentality. 

The Downtown Experience
The cabaret world below the upscale supper clubs tends to divide into two branches. There are thriving clubs, like Don't Tell Mama on Restaurant Row, that rely on a high turnover of showcase acts (many with Broadway stars in their eyes) who are expected to fill the room with friends and supporters. In Greenwich Village, the Duplex Cabaret Theater is experiencing a renewal by booking acts like the lusty pop-rock belter Baby Jane Dexter, who is appearing Saturdays in an open-ended run. Nearby is the venerable piano bar and showcase club, Rose's Turn, a Village institution.
But the future Norah Joneses are more likely to come from a downtown axis of clubs whose performers gleefully fuzz the boundaries between old and new, and between pop, rock, jazz, rhythm-and-blues, swing, country, world music and performance art. At the nexus of the scene is Joe's Pub, the thriving satellite of the Joseph Papp Public Theater, where more than 700 acts appear each year, seven nights a week. Most perform there without the kind of weekly guarantees that uptown supper clubs provide.
The talent is not limited to unknowns. The stars who appear where the prices are reasonable and the hipness quotient high include Ute Lemper, Richard Thompson, Sandra Bernhard, Audra McDonald, Jimmy Scott and Maria Muldaur.
The downtown circuit, which has few points of intersection with the more theater-oriented clubs, now draws record company talent scouts. The clubs include the Living Room on the Lower East Side, the Cutting Room in the Flatiron district, the Slipper Room on the Lower East Side, Fez in the East Village, the Starlight Bar and Lounge on the Lower East Side and, in Brooklyn, the BAM Cafe in Fort Greene and Pete's Candy Store in Williamsburg.
A sampling of the downtown performers who have amassed followings includes David Driver (who performs the Scott Walker songbook with the Loser's Lounge Band), Raul Midon (a rhythm-and-blues singer-songwriter and virtuoso guitarist), Julian Fleisher (offbeat swing versions of vintage pop, rock and soul hits as well as original songs), Morley (earthy, cosmopolitan soul with a spiritual bent), and the singer-songwriters Gavin DeGraw, Jen Chapin and Rebecca Martin.
For these young performers, the pantheon of songwriting giants doesn't end at Rodgers and Hammerstein or Stephen Sondheim, but extends through Joni Mitchell, Leonard Cohen (whose song "Hallelujah" has become a kind of downtown equivalent to "As Time Goes By"), Marvin Gaye, Billy Joel, Randy Newman, Stevie Wonder and Tom Waits.

Selling the Genre
The cabaret field has no more ardent promoter than Donald Smith, the executive director of the Mabel Mercer Foundation, which each fall produces the Cabaret Convention, an annual convocation of performers (both well-known and obscure) that began at Town Hall in 1989, with marathon showcases that are usually sold out. In recent years, Mr. Smith has extended the convention to Chicago, Philadelphia, San Francisco and Palm Springs, and in mid-July he will bring 36 performers to the John Drew Theater at Guild Hall in East Hampton, N.Y., for three nights.
Mr. Smith's tastes run toward traditional, elegant cabaret that puts a premium on smart patter and canny theatrical presentation and reveres the ghosts of Noel Coward, Gertrude Lawrence, Cole Porter and, above all, Mabel Mercer, who more or less invented the intimate cabaret style known as parlando and who died in 1984.
In his promotional efforts for the genre, Mr. Smith has traveled all over the United States. He reports that almost every major city has a club that presents some form of cabaret, although the distinctions between jazz and cabaret frequently blur. Besides Feinstein's at the Cinegrill in Los Angeles, some of the more notable are Davenport's in Chicago, Scullers Jazz Club in Boston, Blues Alley in Washington, Odette's in New Hope, Pa., the Royal Room in Palm Beach, Fla., and the Manor in West Orange, N.J.
But despite some occasional crossover, there is an enormous communications gap between the exclusive, rarefied, uptown concept of cabaret, for which Mr. Smith carries the torch, and the more open-ended, populist downtown scene exemplified by Joe's Pub. The sooner these worlds can reconcile and begin a conversation, the healthier the fragile cabaret field is likely to become.

A Vibrant Scene

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Column 3; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 3916 words

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

Opera

"THE MERRY WIDOW," Bronx Opera. For some 35 years, the Bronx Opera has been a people's company, giving chances to talented younger singers and presenting affordable productions in English translation in a commodious auditorium, the Lovinger Theater at Lehman College in the Bronx. This weekend the company presents a new production of Lehar's elegant operetta "The Merry Widow," conducted by the artistic director and founder, Michael Spierman, though an assistant conductor, Eric Kramer, will preside over tonight's performance. The production is directed by Ben Spierman. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Lovinger Theater, Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx, (718) 960-8833. Tickets: $15-$30. (Anthony Tommasini)

Classical Music

BARGEMUSIC. With its view of the Manhattan skyline and its live, intimate acoustics, this barge floating on the East River is one of the finest places in the city to hear chamber music. Tonight and Sunday, Mark Peskanov, violinist, and Steven Beck, pianist, play three sonatas by Bach (BWV 1017-19) and works by Gyorgy Kurtag. Tomorrow, Andrew Armstrong, pianist, plays Mussorgsky's "Pictures at an Exhibition" and joins Mr. Peskanov and Edward Arron, a cellist, in Tchaikovsky's A-minor Trio. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30; Sunday afternoon at 4. Fulton Ferry Landing, under the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083. Tickets: $35; $20 for students (James R. Oestreich).

BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC. Whether or not these two New York premieres are the food of love, they are definitely inspired by Shakespeare. George Benjamin's "Sometime Voices" is based on one of Caliban's speeches from "The Tempest," and Hans Werner Henze's Symphony No. 8 draws from "A Midsummer Night's Dream." In keeping with the theme, a performance of Act III from Verdi's "Falstaff" will follow. The fiery music director Robert Spano leads the orchestra, soloists and the Canticum Novum Singers. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Brooklyn Academy of Music, Howard Gilman Opera House, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100. Tickets: $20 to $55 (Jeremy Eichler).

FREDERIC CHIU. In a rather absurd historical coincidence, Prokofiev and Stalin died on the same day in 1953 (March 5). That makes this an anniversary year for the composer (not to mention his tormentor), and the pianist Frederic Chiu observes the occasion with a discussion and performance of Prokofiev's monumental wartime Sonata No. 8, completing a three-part series that included No. 6 and No. 7. Tonight at 7, Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 570-3949. Tickets: $30; $15 for students (Eichler).

DESSOFF CHOIRS. In a program called "Musica de Nueva Espana," this well-trained choir turns its attention to the Spanish musical influence in the New World. Included are Renaissance and Baroque sacred settings from Latin America, as well as works by more recent composers, among them Alberto Ginastera. Tomorrow night at 7:30, Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street, (212) 831-8224. Tickets: $35 to $50 (Allan Kozinn).

ELYSIUM. This chamber ensemble, led by the wonderful violinist Eriko Sato, includes members of the New York Philharmonic, Qiang Tu, a cellist, and L. William Kuyper, a horn player. David Oei is the guest pianist. The program offers works of Telemann, Schubert and Mendelssohn. Sunday night at 8:30, Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $35; $15 for students and 62+ (Oestreich).

MET ORCHESTRA. James Levine and the Met Orchestra, having commemorated Berlioz's bicentenary at home with "Les Troyens" (and looking forward to "Benvenuto Cellini" next season), continue the festivities nearby with two Berlioz programs. Or rather one and a half, since each program is anchored by the "Symphonie Fantastique." In the first, Olga Borodina sings "Le Mort de Cleopatre"; in the second, Michael Ouzounian is the viola soloist in "Harold in Italy." Tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday at 3 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: tonight, $39 to $177; Sunday, $39 to $152 (Oestreich).

EDGAR MEYER. For the second of its concerts intended to bring top-notch music to the people of New York free, the new, nonprofit "Free for All at Town Hall" has turned to Edgar Meyer, the eclectic double-bass soloist (now there's a term you seldom hear) who won a MacArthur "genius grant" last year for his distinctive music. This concert shows Mr. Meyer in his characteristic range, from Vivaldi to Schubert to a number of his own compositions (including "The Great Green Sea Snake"). Amy Dorfman, a longtime collaborator of the bassist, is the accompanist. Sunday afternoon at 5, Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 707-8787. Free; tickets are required, and are available at the box office on the day of the performance (Anne Midgette).

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. Kurt Masur conducts, concluding a three-week stint with the orchestra, his first return as music director emeritus. The program is vintage Masur: Brahms's First Symphony and Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto, with Nicholas Angelich as pianist (replacing Maurizio Pollini, who canceled because of back problems). Mr. Angelich, a young American, makes his Philharmonic debut. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $34 to $108 (Oestreich).

MURRAY PERAHIA. The pianist Murray Perahia seems at his artistic peak. His only shortcoming is that he has mostly hewed to the standard Classical and Romantic era repertory and avoided exploring the contemporary music. Living composers would surely line up to write for him, if he were interested. But all the works he will play on Sunday's recital at Carnegie Hall are ideally suited to his intelligence, temperament and exquisite pianism: Bach's Partita No. 4; Beethoven's late Piano Sonata, Op. 101, and Schubert's late Piano Sonata in A. Sunday at 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, 881 Seventh Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $37-$94. (Tommasini)

ST. LAWRENCE QUARTET. This Canadian group, widely regarded as the best of the younger generation of string quartets, has given some incendiary readings of Tchaikovsky and Shostakovich in New York in recent seasons, but this weekend it is playing two concerts devoted mostly to new music. Tonight at Weill Recital Hall, the group is playing Osvaldo Golijov's haunting "Yiddishbbuk," written for the St. Lawrence when both Mr. Golijov and the quartet were in residence at Tanglewood. Also at Tanglewood that summer was the Ying Quartet, another fine group that established a fast friendship with the St. Lawrence players. Two of the Yings -- Phillip Ying, the violist, and David Ying, the cellist -- are to join the St. Lawrence in Schoenberg's "Verklarte Nacht." Also on the program is Mozart's Viola Quintet in G minor (K. 516). On Sunday the St. Lawrence gets up early to play John Adams's "John's Book of Alleged Dances" and the String Quartet No. 2 by Christopher Hatzis, a Canadian composer, at Lincoln Center. Tonight at 8, Weill Recital Hall, Carnegie Hall, 881 Seventh Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $42. Sunday at 11 a.m., Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $18 (Kozinn)

ANDRE WATTS. As part of the Great Performers series, this prominent American pianist returns to Lincoln Center for a solo recital of bread-and-butter repertory: Schubert's Klavierstuck No. 1 (D. 946), his Sonata in A minor (D. 784) and his "Wanderer" Fantasy; three Chopin etudes, Debussy's "Estampes" and selections from Ravel's charming "Miroirs." Sunday afternoon at 3. Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway at 65th Street, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $30 to $50 (Eichler).

Dance

ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER. Ailey will be celebrated in a program of excerpts and his full "Revelations" (tonight and tomorrow afternoon). A second program includes "Winter in Lisbon," a warm breeze of a ballet by Billy Wilson, as well as Ronald K. Brown's "Serving Nia" and Elisa Monte's "Treading," with "Revelations" as the finale (tomorrow night and Sunday afternoon). Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. Sunday at 3 p.m. New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722. Tickets: $16 to $69 (Jennifer Dunning).

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER. The company will present "La Bayadere" -- to some the quintessential experience of classical ballet -- in this opening weekend of its eight-week spring season. To start there is the exquisitely beautiful "Kingdom of the Shades" act, in which the faltering hero gets stoned and imagines that he is dancing with the dead lover he has justbetrayed. The dancers performing the lead roles of Nikiya, Solor, Gamzatti and the Bronze Idol are Julie Kent, Ethan Stiefel, Irina Dvorovenko and Herman Cornejo (tonight); Nina Ananiashvili, Julio Bocca, Gillian Murphy and Carlos Lopez (tomorrow afternoon); and Alina Cojocaru, Angel Corella, Stella Abrera and Joaquin De Luz (tomorrow night). Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8. Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center (212) 362-6000. Tickets: $20 to $155. In conjunction with the season, an exhibition and sale of photographs of Ballet Theater dancers by Nancy Ellison will run through June 7 at the Gallery at Lincoln Center, on the Concourse Level of Lincoln Center, (212) 580-4673. Gallery hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. (Dunning).

BLACK DANCE: TRADITION AND TRANSFORMATION. This vibrant and thought-provoking two-week series opens with the Ronald K. Brown/Evidence company in "Dirt Road" and excerpts from "Destiny," created in collaboration with the Jeune Ballet d'Afrique Noire. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Brooklyn Academy of Music, Harvey Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100. Tickets: $20 to $40 (Dunning).

BOOGIE DOWN DANCE SERIES 2003 AT BAAD!: ARTHUR AVILES TYPICAL THEATER. Mr. Aviles and his dancers will present a program of short solo works and a duet called "The Naked Bald Man and the Goddess" that draw on social or club dancing as well as modern dance to explore, as Mr. Aviles puts it, "hope in the eye of dumbfounded chaos." Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance (BAAD!), 841 Barretto Street, Hunts Point, (718) 842-5223. Tickets: $12 (Dunning).

BOSTON BALLET. Yes, it's that ballet ("Romeo and Juliet") to that music (Prokofiev's), but this time choreographed by Rudi van Dantzig. Tonight (and next Tuesday and Friday) at 8; tomorrow (and next Saturday) at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday (and next Sunday) at 2 p.m.; Wednesday and Thursday at 7 p.m. Wang Theater, 270 Tremont Street, Boston, (800) 447-7400. Tickets: $12.50 to $82 (Dunning).

ROXANE BUTTERFLY. A French-born tap choreographer with an all-female company celebrates the energy of life with tap, hip-hop, Afro-Cuban and jazz dancing and the rhythms of the spoken word. Tonight at 8:30, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400. Tickets: $21 (Jack Anderson).

CONTEMPORARY BALLET THEATER. Founded and directed by the dancer and choreographer known as Pepper, this company will perform as part of the Through Her Eyes: Women of Color Performing Arts and Film Festival 2003. Tonight at 7:15; tomorrow night at 7; Sunday at 3:45 p.m. Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side, (212) 501-3842 or www.womenofcolorpro.citymax.com. HAROLD (STUMPY) CROMER AND TAP SENSATIONS. HEADLINE: Toyota Profit for Last Year Sets Recordfor Automakers 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 8 

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation reported strong gains in profits for 2002 and one of the largest net income figures in the automotive industry's history today, mainly because of strong demand in the United States. But the company said its three-year run of strong profit growth is in jeopardy in the current year because of sluggish economic growth around the world.
 Toyota joined Honda Motor, Nissan and Mitsubishi Motors in reaching new financial peaks in the latest fiscal year, which ended March 31. Toyota has been able to outsell its American rivals without relying nearly as heavily as they do on cash incentives to draw buyers. And the higher fuel prices and uncertain economy in the United States have tended to favor Toyota and the other Japanese makers, because their cars are more fuel-efficient and are seen as more reasonably priced. 
 These advantages, along with a one-time gain from the sale of pension assets, helped Toyota record 945 billion yen ($8.1 billion) in net income for the latest fiscal year, a gain of 53.4 percent from the prior year. None of the Big Three American car manufacturers have ever reported so large a profit. Ford Motor came closest in 1997, with $6.9 billion.
Operating profits, which more closely reflect Toyota's ability to sell cars, rose 27 percent, to 1.4 trillion yen ($12 billion), in the latest period; sales increased 6.3 percent, to 16.1 trillion yen. The figures were at the lower end of most analysts' expectations.
Though Toyota executives said they were encouraged by the company's strong showing in the United States in the the first four months of the 2003 calendar year, they were guarded about prospects for the months to come. Worldwide, the company expects car sales to grow by less than 1 percent in 2003, they said, and Toyota may be able to increase operating profits only if the yen weakens against the dollar.
"It is very hard to predict where the foreign exchange market is going," said Ryuji Araki, a Toyota executive vice president. Still, Mr. Araki said, the strong reception for new Corolla and Highlander models in the United States means that Toyota may sell more than two million cars in North America this year.
Toyota is stepping up production in the United States to further insulate it from the vagaries of exchange rates, to reduce inventories and to shorten delivery times to dealers. It plans to build a factory in San Antonio that will make Tundra trucks, starting in 2006. And a new version of the Prius electric-gas hybrid car is due this fall.
Toyota is also devoting attention to Japan, where it controls 42.3 percent of the market. The company sold about the same number of cars in the latest fiscal year as in the year before, but revenue from those sales grew 6.9 percent. The Toyota Wish minivan was the best-selling vehicle in Japan in April, the first time a minivan topped the list. The Corolla was second, outpacing compact cars from Honda and Nissan. In all, 6 of the top 10 were Toyotas.
The company also plans to combine some of its dealerships in Japan and to introduce Lexus, its luxury brand, to its home market. Last month, Toyota announced plans to speed up decision making in the company by cutting the size of its board in half and, for the first time, appointing non-Japanese directors.
Ultimately, though, Toyota and other Japanese carmakers make the bulk of their money in the United States. Toyota's lineup remains popular there, but the average age of its buyers is rising. To keep its brands fresh and sales growing, Toyota, Honda and Nissan each must come up with models that can attract younger Americans, as Volkswagen and Hyundai have done.
"The Gordian knot for Toyota is that its cars are so popular with baby boomers that it turns off the Gen X crowd," said Chris Richter, an auto analyst at HSBC Securities in Tokyo. "If you can't change with the new generation, your customers will eventually get old and die."

HEADLINE: Fed Is Startingto Fret Over Falling Prices 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
In deciding this week to keep short-term interest rates at 1.25 percent, the Federal Reserve Board warned of "an unwelcome substantial fall in inflation." The topic also came up at its March meeting, according to minutes released yesterday. Economists have been talking about the dangers of falling prices for several months, but why did the Fed take note now? 
 First of all, some experts believe that the risk of deflation has increased of late. Commodity prices have been dropping for years, but now energy prices, after a spike leading up to the war in Iraq, have also slipped. 
 Most important, however, is the absence of an engine to drive the economy forward. With weak demand, prices could begin to fall in widespread fashion. 
Ethan S. Harris, the chief economist of Lehman Brothers, puts the chance of broad deflation in the near future at about 25 percent. "You need weak economic activity for one and a half or two years" for deflation to occur, he said. "You never get the boom that's going to heal the economy."
Another concern is that the Fed is running out of leverage against deflation. 
Though it took no action on Tuesday, several Wall Street banks expect it to cut short-term interest rates to 0.75 percent before July. As short-term rates edge closer to zero, expanding the money supply -- the method the Fed uses for lowering rates -- might have little effect on the ease of obtaining credit. Interest rates could not fall below zero, after all. Economists call this state of affairs a liquidity trap.
"It's right for the Fed to be concerned about it and talking about it," said Laurence M. Ball, a professor of economics at Johns Hopkins University. "The key thing to look at is not any particular price level, but the interest rate. When it hits zero, then you're in trouble."
Professor Ball did not predict that interest rates would fall to zero, but he warned that an unexpected shock to the economy could be more damaging with rates so low."When you're walking along the side of a cliff, the closer you are to it, the more dangerous it is," he said. "There's no particular chance you're going to fall off it, but there's always the chance you'll get jostled."
Falling prices might not sound like such a bad thing, at least from a consumer's point of view. Moreover, deflation can be a side effect of a healthy economic development, like the surges in efficiency that have steadily lowered the prices of personal computers. 
But what the Fed is worried about now, the experts said, is deflation arising as a symptom of the economy's frailty. And falling prices could cause some real problems by themselves.
For example, rapid deflation can cause a huge redistribution of income and wealth from debtors to creditors, said Willem H. Buiter, a former member of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee.
When prices are expected to fall, interest rates tend to fall, too. If prices are lower tomorrow than they are today, a dollar will be worth more tomorrow in terms of what it can buy. And the more borrowers think that prices will fall in the future, the less they will be willing to pay in interest on loans. Similarly, existing loans with fixed interest rates become more valuable to lenders -- and more onerous to borrowers -- as prices fall.
"That kind of redistribution is often very painful because it causes all sort of distress," Mr. Buiter said, like corporate insolvencies and defaults by banks.
Deflation can also cause problems for companies with fairly inflexible costs of doing business, Mr. Harris said. "The auto industry has a pretty rigid cost structure, and obviously they'd like to see some inflation in the economy," he said. "Instead, what they're getting is they have to keep cutting the prices of their vehicles."
Mr. Harris also said expectations for deflation -- if not brought on by a "productivity revolution" that makes the economy much more efficient -- could themselves perpetuate economic weakness. If people think prices will fall in the future, they will postpone purchases. After two years of weakness, he said, "we already have a little element of the deflation psychology in the economy."
Some economists have also argued that falling prices for goods and services could lead to falling wages -- something workers might find intolerable. But Professor Ball said there was little evidence to support that idea. "There has actually been a number of studies in the past few years looking at wages, and finding that wages do fall in certain circumstances and there doesn't seem to be such a taboo about it."
The consequences of deflation are on display, of course, in Japan which has experienced deflation for the last three years after a decade of economic weakness. Japan's troubles began in 1990 when a huge crash in prices of real estate and securities suddenly depressed the willingness of consumers and businesses to spend. In the midst of deflation, short-term interest rates eventually fell to zero, largely handcuffing the central bank.
Well aware of Japan's striking example, the Fed's governors have been barnstorming the country in recent months to assure the public that, even with low interest rates, they still have tools to fight deflation. In a speech in December, the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said the Fed could buy Treasury bonds with long maturities to drive down long-term interest rates. In January, a Fed governor, Edward M. Gramlich, said that with interest rates at zero, a rapid expansion in the money supply might still be enough to stop deflation. 
But some economists have remained skeptical.
"It's probably a good thing for them to say, 'Oh, don't worry, we have a lot of tools to deal with it,' " Professor Ball said. "That bolsters confidence, and is maybe good for the economy. Having said that, I'm not sure it's true that they have lots of tools. If there were any really obvious tools that the central banks could use to get you right out of a liquidity trap, Japan would have done it."
In fact, both Mr. Buiter and Professor Ball argued that in situations like Japan's, central banks should make way for the lawmakers who control taxes and spending.
"It is always both technically and politically dead easy to stop deflation and get rid of it, if you don't want it," Mr. Buiter said. "It is not necessary for these things to persist. The government should immediately prime the pump and send the checks to all deserving and undeserving Americans."
Professor Ball agreed. "The textbook solution to a liquidity trap is a fiscal expansion, and there's every reason to think that would work." In a situation of low demand and deflation, he said, "before too long, enough political pressure would build up for a big fiscal expansion."
Unfortunately for Japan, this escape plan was hard to carry out. Japan's overwhelming debt burden limited the government's ability to cut taxes or spend money. And its problems ran deeper than weak demand and deflation.
"Deflation is kind of the icing on the cake," Mr. Harris said. "The big problem in Japan is the big failure to deal with the problems in the banking system. No stimulative policy is going to work if your financial system isn't functioning -- if the process of getting funds from savers to borrowers breaks down."
The United States, the experts said, is not mired in similar straits. The financial system is healthy, and, Mr. Buiter pointed out, the boom and bust in asset markets was far smaller in the United States than in Japan.
"Real estate and house prices never went on the kind of walkabout that they did in Japan," he said. "There is no parallel between what Japan has been going through for the last 10 years- plus now and what lies in store for the United States."
Professor Ball added that the government here had more latitude to fight deflation in the event of a liquidity trap. "Even though our long-term fiscal situation is not great, it's not as bad as Japan's," he said.
On that point, however, Mr. Harris was not equally sanguine. "When you get into a deflation environment and you're trying to get the economy going, there aren't any really easy solutions," he said. "Usually when you get to deflation, you already have a significant budget deficit. That's in fact true for the U.S."

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Exceed 400,000 for a 12thWeek 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8 

 BODY:
Applications for initial unemployment benefits exceeded 400,000 for a 12th consecutive week, the Labor Department said today, the longest stretch since the economy was emerging from a recession in 1992.
 Jobless claims dropped to 425,000 last week from 453,000 in the prior week, the Labor Department said. 
Some economists consider claims above 400,000 a sign of slack demand for workers. 
 Companies are trimming payrolls to shore up profits after the weakest three months of consumer spending in a decade.
"These persistently high claims pose a significant threat to the prospects of a second-half upturn since weak job conditions make consumers more cautious about spending," said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. Claims reached a 13-month high of 459,000 in the week that ended April 19.
Federal Reserve policy makers kept the benchmark interest rate at the lowest since 1961 earlier this week and said they expected growth to pick up later this year.
Economists had estimated that claims last week would fall to 440,000 from the initially reported 448,000 a week earlier, based on the median of 35 forecasts. The less-volatile four-week moving average of claims rose 3,250, to 446,000, the highest since mid-April last year.
The number of people continuing to collect state unemployment benefits rose to 3.665 million in the week that ended April 26. That was the highest in six months.
"What is worrying is that continuing claims continue to rise," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM MoneyWatch in New York. "It confirms that the jobless are having a lot of trouble finding jobs. The bottom line is there is no improvement yet" in the job market.

HEADLINE: Fed's Views on Prices in March 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHI NGTON, May 8 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee was already mulling the possibility of disinflation at its March meeting, well before its acknowledgment this week that a slowing in price rises was a possibility, minutes released today showed.
 "Inflation would likely remain subdued," the minutes of the March 18 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee said. "Indeed, members saw further disinflation in core prices as a distinct possibility over the next several quarters." 
 The committee at its most recent meeting on Tuesday had noted the possibility of an "unwelcome substantial fall in inflation," although it also said the probability of that was "minor."
The summary of the March minutes, released with a seven-week delay, showed that the issue was already on the minds of policy makers before Tuesday and might cause further discussion about deflation. Deflation is an outright fall in prices usually accompanied by a severe slump in economic activity.
The committee refrained from changing interest rates at the March meeting, even as some of its members worried that the uncertainty of the Iraq war and a slowing economy were taking their toll.
"While the economic expansion had displayed signs of faltering in recent weeks, the reasons for, and hence the duration of any period of weakness, could not be reliably ascertained," the minutes said.
Such doubts led the committee to abandon its usual statement about whether the risks to the economy were balanced evenly or leaning toward weakness or inflation.
"Most members believed that the major uncertainties surrounding the geopolitical situation made it impossible to assign reasonable probabilities to plausible alternative economic outcomes and that any effort to do so would provide a misleading impression of the committee's confidence and knowledge about the economic outlook," the minutes said.
The F.O.M.C. also held rates steady at Tuesday's meeting.
