HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Selling Spas and Castle Views

BYLINE:  By TANYA MOHN 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
STAINED-GLASS windows by Matisse and Chagall. Spas. Formal gardens. Sweeping river views amid sculptures by Picasso and Brancusi. Castles.
No, these aren't stops on a grand tour of Europe. They are some of the local attractions that Margo Jones, the director of tourism for Westchester County, promotes to entice the public to visit as the summer tourism season approaches. 
 "When people think of us, we want to give them a creative image," Ms. Jones said. 
 That's the strategy she used to plan a new poster portraying nine castles that look like they would be more at home in the Irish countryside or the Loire Valley than in Westchester.
"Gee, I didn't know you had so many castles. I want to go there, I want to see that" -- that is the response Ms. Jones said she wants to provoke. 
The castles offer everything from overnight accommodations to afternoon tea. The Castle at Tarrytown, a Norman-style structure, now a 31-room inn, graces the highest point in the county. Whitby Castle in Rye, containing stones from the original Whitby Abbey in England, is a restaurant. Caramoor, a Mediterranean-style mansion in Katonah, has rooms filled with furniture from European palaces and villas.
Travel is essential to the county where more than 30,000 jobs are affected by local tourism. And in Westchester, as in the country, tourism is off, dropping from $1.7 billion in 2000 to $1.4 billion in 2001. 
To promote travel, the county has a tourism budget of $770,000 annually, most of it raised by a tax on hotel rooms in the county. 
The push on local tourism began in 2000, during County Executive Andrew J. Spano's first term. Richard K. Gsottschneider, president of RKG Associates, a consulting firm based in Durham, N.H., was hired to develop an economic plan for the county. 
His study found that tourism was responsible for about 10 percent of the county's employment base and was tied in to the many corporate headquarters clustered in the county. 
The Office of Tourism, which had been in the private sector as part of the County Chamber of Commerce, becamepart of county government Jan. 1, 2001, when Ms. Jones was hired.
Earlier in her career, Ms. Jones ran the statewide "I Love New York" campaign from February 1992 to January 1995. 
One of the first things Ms. Jones did was to move the tourism office from the basement to a more prominent location on Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains. She made an official tourism map and streamlined the distribution of other material. 
"Some of the basic tools needed to sell Westchester as a destination, we didn't have," she said. 
But it was a tough economic time, compounded by Sept. 11, 2001, and its aftermath.
The travel industry was "really pushed off a cliff" said Cathy Keefe, a spokeswoman for the Travel Industry Association of America, based in Washington. Domestic travel before 2000 was a $570 billion industry nationally. It has since dropped to $537 billion.
National Tourism Week, which this year runs from May 10 to 18, was created 20 years ago as a way to impress upon local communities how much tourism can contribute to their economies. This summer, "there is less interest in big cities and more interest in smaller towns and rural villages," she said.
"The areas a couple of hours from major cities are most likely to do quite well." 
Part of Ms. Jones' strategy is to locate niche markets. A brochure "Antiques the Westchester Way," touting close to 50 shops and auction houses, a detailed map and a calendar of shows and events, has a been sent out.
A brochure featuring Westchester's gardens was recently completed, and another on "soft adventures," like bird watching, hiking and Rollerblading, is planned. Two fall driving tours were produced last year, and another is in the works.
A tourism information center is being built in an abandoned gas station on the northbound side of the Bronx River Parkway, at exit 9 near Scarsdale, with the opening planned for June 27. It will be packed with brochures and fliers, a book of menus from area restaurants and information about tickets for shows. Pay phones as well as courtesy phones provided by the county will be available to book dinner and hotel reservations. Hotels, sites and restaurants will pay to have their information available, which will contribute to the costs of running the center. Ms. Jones estimates the center's budget at $8,000 to $10,000 a year. 
It isn't only the leisure tourist the county is after. Tonya Inman, the director of sales and marketing for the Crowne Plaza Hotel in White Plains, said that traditionally many professional groups have held conventions and meetings in upstate New York, where the rates are lower. But the tourism office now sends representatives to about a dozen travel and industry trade shows a year, and the increased marketing has helped local hotels and organizations find one another. "It's like having a satellite sales office," Ms. Inman said.

Day-Tripping In Young Suburbia
TOURISM born of economic necessity is not new for Westchester County.
In the early 19th century, hotels began springing up along Long Island Sound and the Hudson River for the masses who couldn't afford country homes but who wanted to escape the humid and muggy New York City summers for the weekend. After the Civil War, steamboat excursions became a popular means of escape. Day-trippers would come up to visit picnic groves dotting the county's coastline. John Starin, owner of a steamboat line, bought Glen Island in New Rochelle in 1879, to make a picnic grove. It quickly became one of the most popular resorts of its day, operating for close to a quarter century with thousands of visitors flocking to see its aviary with exotic birds, tropical gardens, wild animals, even a natural history museum with specimens from around the world, including the mummified body of an 18-year-old Egyptian princess. Authentic Indian war dances and villages transplanted from the Philippines added to the allure. 
"It was a 19th-century Disney World on the Sound," said Marilyn Weigold, a history professor at Pace University, who wrote a two-part article in 2001 for The Westchester Historian, a publication of the Westchester County Historical Society. 
By the early part of the 20th century, the county became less of a tourist destination, as more people moved to the suburbs. TANYA MOHN

CORRECTION-DATE: June 8, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 11 about efforts to increase tourism in Westchester referred incorrectly to the altitude of the Castle at Tarrytown, an inn. At 450 feet, it is not the highest point in the county. Bailey Mountain, in North Salem, is 980 feet above sea level.

HEADLINE: Back to the Future In Transportation 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 It is good to read that New Jersey Transit and the Department of Transportation are placing a great deal of focus on restoring train station buildings across the state ("Trains, Porches and History," By the Way, May 4). 
 Actually, an increasing number of public and private transportation professionals around the country are seeing the benefit of going back to the future by making train stations centers of community activity in towns that grew up around them. Through public agency programs known as Context Sensitive Design and Transit-Friendly Communities, transportation facilities are being developed that preserve scenic, aesthetic and historic resources while maintaining safety and mobility for all involved.
 As in Oradell, such efforts enable New Jersey Transit to work with towns that have visions of an economically successful, vibrant and friendly downtown. On the Morris and Essex Line's Gladstone branch, South Orange, now a transit-friendly community, has given its station attractive pedestrian and retail features to make it fit better within the town's character. As a result, the train station, no longer just a barren place used only by commuters, has been "reclaimed" into the community and is a more pleasant experience for other residents who can use it as a gathering point. The new Union Station across from Kean College on the Raritan Valley Line is another example of a commitment to meeting transportation needs through transit-friendly investments and efficient use of public resources.

Steven P. Scalici
Staten Island

The writer is a transportation engineer.

HEADLINE: The Business of Education 

BYLINE:  By KEN STIER 

DATELINE: HOBOKEN 

 BODY:
FORTY years after watching Stevens Institute of Technology miss out on revolutionary advances in aerospace, Frank Fernandez is back at his alma mater to try to make sure the 133-year old institution does not miss out on the next wave.
 "When I was there in the late 1950's and early 1960's aerospace was the technology," said Mr. Fernandez, who was the Pentagon's research director in the Clinton administration. "I mean, Kennedy, we were going to go the moon, the Russians, the space race, all that, and Stevens would not start a strong fluid mechanics program because a lot of the faculty in mechanical engineering thought this was another passing fancy. That frustrated the hell out of me." 
 It also sent him packing. After earning an undergraduate degree at Stevens, he moved to California to pursue his passion for what became known as aerospace engineering, earning a doctorate at the California Institute of Technology and then burrowing ever deeper into the belly of the military-industrial complex. 
 These days Mr. Fernandez is director of Stevens's office of technology initiatives, where he is responsible for boosting "research revenues" and for managing any resulting intellectual property. He seems to be delivering. The Defense Department has increased its research contracts with Stevens to $8.8 million, from $4.8 million in 2000. Overall, the school's current billed research is $11.3 million, all but asmall fraction from Washington. 
 Compared with university behemoths like Johns Hopkins -- which in 2000 received close to gets $800 million from the federal government -- it is modest. But in its own universe of small private technical institutes, Stevens has set ambitious goals. 
 Even while he was establishing three research companies in California, Mr. Fernandez kept an eye half-cocked across the continent. He watched with some dismay as a flat-footed Stevens failed to catch later technological waves -- in semiconductors and then information technology. And he remembered how a school in Cleveland that "we used to play in lacrosse" -- Case Western Reserve University -- "grew into the powerhouse it is today."
 Now Stevens, which has a remarkably low profile, even in its hometown, has another chance to break into the ranks of internationally recognized research institutes. 
 This time the school has even created its own trademark -- Technogenesis -- which it defines as a process by which students, faculty and industry jointly nurture new technologies from concept to the marketplace. While some critics scoff at its originality, few schools have committed themselves as zealously as Stevens to injecting an entrepreneurial edge throughout the educational process.

'Special Time' at Stevens
 The proof of Technogenesis lies years off, in the successes of graduates and the companies they may help to create. Both are critically dependent on revving up the institute's research role.
 "Stevens is at that kind of special time when one of those waves has been building having to do with research needed for meeting our country's new strategic needs as result of the war on terrorism and the crash of the telecom industry," Mr. Fernandez said. "Stevens can grab this one and it can take it a long ways, or if it doesn't, this will just right go by it and Stevens can go back to the way it was 10 years ago."
 For now, Stevens mostly radiates readiness to seize the opportunity and, at least among administrators and some faculty, Technogenesis is invoked as a mantra -- sometimes to an odd degree. For instance, the annual report even contends Technogenesis takes place in its theatrical productions. The institute's president, Harold Raveche, is the prime booster, and he has a weekly television program called -- not surprisingly -- "Technogenesis," which is broadcast every Sunday night on CN8.
 A more solid indication of Stevens's commitment to practice what it preaches is its redoubled efforts to launch institute-generated technology companies, even at the expense of current programs. For instance, many were puzzled by a recent decision to close the school's state-financed program that for 11 years has nurtured dozens of start-up businesses -- even before the financing was expected to dry up in June with the planned elimination of the state science and technology commission. But the school says that closing the incubator will allow it to focus on institute-affiliated companies, in which it has an undisclosed equity stake.
 "To me they are very brave in being as aggressive as they are in that technology transfer operation, putting as much into it as they have," Michael Breton, an associate vice president for research at Rutgers, said in a recent interview. "It's a great experiment. Given the size of their research base, I really have to hand it to them for having that kind of confidence."
 Stevens is not shy about letting on that it has sprouted companies with billion-dollar possibilities. Most promising are two companies based on a fundamental breakthrough in the physics of plasma -- a form of energized gas -- achieved by Erich Kunhardt, dean of the school of arts and sciences, who has taught at Texas Tech University and at the Polytechnic Institute of New York.
 Two other companies derive from the expertise of a Russian-born physicist, Dimitri Donskoy, who once had a career hunting American submarines before defecting just ahead of the collapse of the Soviet Union. These days, he is applying those skills to help locate other things -- from underground land mines for the Army to termites for victimized homeowners.
 A fifth company, Hydroglobe, is bringing to the world market the expertise it developed helping to clean up water at Picatinny Arsenal, a weapons testing center near Dover. 
 As promising as these companies are, however, making billions -- at least for now --remains a long shot. Good technology is no guarantee for making a good business, and most of these fledging companies are still taking their first baby steps. 
 One of the firms that grew out of Dr. Kunhardt's technology, Plasmion, recently signed a $2.25 million partnership with a South Korean firm (Hanwha L&C Corporation), though Stevens officials concede major "liquidity events" -- like the Holy Grail of an IPO -- are nowhere in sight.
 In the meantime, Stevens is focused on expanding its research base, which is essential for keeping its pipeline full of new technologies. With swelling budget shortfalls and a corporate sector still licking its wounds in New Jersey, financing for expanded research can only come from the federal government. Tapping into those lucrative pools is largely Mr. Fernandez's responsibility -- with the help of several other recent administrative and faculty appointments.
 For instance, the new dean of the institutes' school of technology management is Jerry Hultin, a former under secretary of the Navy in the Clinton administration, and Paul Kolodzy, director of a new wireless communication security center, oversaw allocation of the airwaves for the Federal Communications Commission.
 As with previous advances in technology, the federal government is the primary engine fueling the huge expenditures in research and development. Historically, these breakthroughs have been largely motivated by national security challenges. 
 These days, the federal government is spending billions of dollars to meet military challenges and to bolster homeland security. And Mr. Fernandez is in a position to help tap into those funds. 
 Before leaving the government, he was director of the Defense Advanced Research Program Agency, which functions as the Pentagon's venture capital arm. This year alone, the agency had a budget of $3 billiion, with as sizeable percentage going toward university research.
 With the aim of bolstering Stevens's role in that effort, Mr. Fernandez says he is on track to bring in $35 million in research money by 2007, and the plan is to level off around $40 million annually. 
 These targets were set after an analysis of the country's top 50 research institutions showed that faculty members were receiving about $300,000 in federal research money. But until recently, the faculty at Stevens -- made up of about 100 fulltime professors -- was supported by an average of less than $100,000 a year for research, including the pay for doctoral students, who do most of the actual lab work. In the next few years, Stevens hopes to hire 50 0r 60 more fulltime professors, using these new sources of money to lure new professors.

Drawing Top Students
 "You are going to be hearing from us," said Dr. Kunhardt, who says that the physics, chemistry and computer science departments can rival any in the country. 
 His boast seems to be reinforced by the caliber of students drawn to Stevens, where the average combined College Board scores are more than 1,300 and whose steep tuition comes close to Ivy League colleges. Tuituion for a full-time undergraduate can run as high as $24,500 a year.
 Full-time undergraduates are approaching a proposed cap of 2,000, and there are several hundred full-time graduate students and more than 2,000 more part-time students doing graduate-level work. 
 As a small, private institution, Stevens has always been a niche player and when on its game, this has allowed it to play a high-level research role. The school's Davidson Laboratory, with its world-renowed wave-testing tank, has done small ship design for the United States Navy for decades --and more recently for foreign governments -- building on the work of Edwin Stevens, a founding family member, who played a major role in developing America's ironclad vessels in the 19th century. 
 Stevens -- situated on a 55-acre riverside promontory with a commanding view of Manhattan --was cited in the log of Henry Hudson's navigator in 1609, and later became the estate of the Stevens' family, English landed gentry who settled here in 1699.
 Because of its attraction as a terrorist target, New York City is a key focus for security research, particularly for ports and wireless communications -- making Stevens an ideal test site. After nearly falling off the Navy's radar, Stevens recently won initial financing from the Office of Naval Research to lead an Anglo-American consortia to work on micro-oceanographic modeling, which will help predict dispersal patterns of water or airborne contaminants. Other work will be directed at surveillance systems -- partly by unmanned ships -- of traffic on, below or above water miles out from the harbor. The research, to be financed by about $6 million a year, will be the focus of the school's new center for maritime systems.
 Successful spin-offs of Stevens-affiliated technology will be an important barometer of the institute's Technogenesis approach, which aims to teach engineers -- still the school's core student constituency -- what it takes to bring new products to market. Until now, the record of schools succeeding in this area is not particularly good, and most university-generated intellectual property ends up sitting on shelves or not selling much. Less than one percent of the roughly 21,000 university patents currently yield royalty payments of more than a million dollars a year, according to the Association of University Technology Managers.
 But that record seems to be improving. It was only with the passage of federal legislation in 1980 known as the Bayh-Dole Act -- named afters its two sponsors, Senators Birch Bayh and Bob Dole -- that universities were allowed, and even encouraged, to profit from government-financed research.
 Today, states are looking more and more to research institutes as critical components of their local economies, particularly in a high-tech states like New Jersey.
 For this reason, many regard as short-sighted Governor McGreevey's decision to cut off financing for the state's Commission for Science and Technology, which provides seed money for researchers to submit more competitive grants application to Washington. As it is, New Jersey is taking in a disproportionately small share of federally financed research, and without any improvement the state will eventually become less attractive as place for high-tech facilities or as source of employment. The state is already falling behind a number of other key rivals -- including Michigan and North Carolina -- that continue to aggressively finance research and development, says Dr. Saul Fenster, the former president of the New Jersey Institute of Technology. 
 With traditional sources of money pinched, universities have new incentive to try to improve their own record of commercialization, though this is a kind of alchemy is not so well understood.
 "I may have a Ph.D. in physics," says Dr. Donskoy, the Rusian acous5tics expert, "but I am probably still in second grade when comes to business." 
 Dr. Kunhardt, the dean of arts and sciences at Stevens and the intellectual, if not spiritual, founder of Technogenesis, largely agrees.
 "To be nice," he said, "I will say that this is as difficult to do as the creation of the technology."
 He speaks from experience. After his invention of cold fire plasma, he formed three companies to devise commercial applications. He brought his students along for the ride, having them sit in on presentations before financial backers. He likened the process to apprentice doctors gathering around an operating table to watch older doctors perform surgery.

Companies Become Classrooms
 Dr. Kundhardt stands to make a fortune if any of his companies take off, but he insists his primary interests lie elsewhere. 
 "Its done as much for the instructional value of it as it is for the introduction of technology into society, and that is where I think we have introduced our own little twist to the whole story," he says. "The companies essentially become a classroom and the whole process becomes a classroom - its like a seamless world."
 In some important ways the new Stevens approach is a return to its roots, since the institute -- the country's first mechanical egineering school -- likes to call the Stevens family the "first family of American inventors." The family patriarch, John Stevens, a Revolutionary War colonel, was a railroad and steamboat pioneer and was instrumental in establishing the country's first patent commission. Indeed, documents from the institute's founding in 1871 -- with its talk of "liberal technical" education -- sound remarkably similar to the descriptions of Technogenesis. 
 "We are trying to reintroduce a kind of Edisonian, Yankee ingenuity", explains Louis Laucirica, the vice dean of Stevens's school of technology management, who spent most of his career in the corporate world. "We are promoting this concept that managing technology is different from management in general. Stevens has the ability to bring both technology and hopefully business to the table -- and that is somewhat unique." 
 Yet there is also a danger that Technongenesis can be taken too far, with research eventually eclipsing teaching or introducing distracting pressure to come up with a blockbuster company. 
 "Most universities presidents focus on their educational and research programs and the commercialization is an activity that they support," said Daryl Boudreaux, who once worked at Stevens and now directs Rice University's office of technology transfer, "but not as a tail wagging the dog but as the tail of a dog that can have significant value in terms of visibility and the earnings it can bring." I think if I were a university president that I would not make it my priority to become a commercialization engine because that seems to me to be changing the nature of the entity."
 Stevens officials say they are well aware of this, and Dr. Kunhardt admits there was considerable resistance among the faculty to Technogenesis at first. But he says that any lingering resistance is due misunderstanding the concept.
 "Most professors, certainly most American professors, would say their job is only to create knowledge," he said. "I say, of course, our job is to create knowledge, but there is also a niche for a university that not only creates knowledge but also creates from that knowledge new technologies that benefit society."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: INSIDE BASEBALL; 
Palmeiro Provides Consistent Power

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Once upon a time, Major League Baseball had an official statistic called the game-winning run batted in. It lived a relatively short life because it was a flawed statistic, but while it existed Rafael Palmeiro was not good at it. In fact, in 152 games in 1988, Palmeiro had 0, that's zero, game-winning R.B.I.
 Little wonder that people said Palmeiro could not drive in big runs. The thought that Palmeiro ever had any hitting deficiencies seems preposterous now, but the Chicago Cubs traded him after that season, and his lack of offensive production has long been believed to have been the reason. 
 "I've gotten a kick over the years that Palmeiro has taken a couple of shots at me," said Jim Frey, who traded Palmeiro to the Texas Rangers. "Most of the time when people take shots, they're doing it with limited information. He had limited information. It wasn't a case of me thinking he wasn't a good hitter. But he seems to take pleasure out of it. If it gives him pleasure, it's good with me." 
Frey, retired and playing golf and gin rummy in southwest Florida, was the Cubs general manager who traded Palmeiro, who entering last night's game against Cleveland was one home run from becoming the 19th to hit 500 home runs.
At the age of 23, Palmeiro hit 8 home runs and drove in 53 runs in 580 at-bats in 1988, his first full season in the majors. Two months after the season, Frey sent him to the Rangers in a nine-player trade that brought the Cubs a closer.
"We found out that the infamous Mitch Williams was available," Frey related. "The fact that he had saved around 30 games or so and he was a hard thrower appealed to us. We also had a chance to acquire Curtis Wilkerson, a utility infielder, which we needed."
The Rangers, Frey recalled, wanted a first baseman, and the Cubs had two, Palmeiro and Mark Grace, a rookie that season. "We thought they were both going to be good offensive players," Frey said, "but we didn't think that either Grace or Palmeiro would have been a good defensive left fielder, so the question was, which one would we trade?"
The Rangers emphatically provided the answer. "It wasn't our choice to peddle Palmeiro, although I'm sure Rafael thinks I just shipped him off to Texas," Frey said. "They chose him. I said how about Grace; they said they wanted Palmeiro."
Tom Grieve, then the Rangers' general manager, confirmed that Palmeiro was his No. 1 target. "We identified our major need as a couple good hitters," Grieve said. "We had an all or nothing lineup. We struck out or hit home runs against secondary pitching, but against good pitching we got shut down regularly. We identified Raffy and Julio Franco."
Grieve said he didn't remember the Cubs offering Grace but said, "If it did come up, we dismissed it quickly because Raffy was the guy we wanted. We would not have made the trade for Grace."
Frey and Grieve agreed on another matter regarding Palmeiro.
"I don't think anyone, including him, thought he would hit 500 home runs," Frey said.
Grieve, a Rangers television analyst, said: "No one can say he thought Raffy would become this kind of player. You just can't do that. We thought Raffy was a .300, 40 doubles, 25 to 30 home runs and 100 R.B.I. guy. No one in his wildest dreams would have thought he could hit 500 home runs."
Fifteen years after the trade, as remarkable as Palmeiro's home run output is, so is the fact that he has never won a league home run championship. Some critics cite that failure as a hole in Palmeiro's Hall of Fame resume, but Grieve disagrees. 
"He doesn't win home run championships," Grieve said, "but the record that's amazing is he's the only hitter in the history of Major League Baseball, including Babe Ruth, to hit 38 home runs eight straight years. That streak negates the argument that he never won a home run title."
The streak lives. In the past eight seasons, Palmeiro hit 39, 39, 38, 43, 47, 39, 47 and 43 home runs. In six of those seasons, some American League hitter (Alex Rodriguez the last two years) hit 50 or more home runs. The closest Palmeiro came to a title in that span was in 1999 when he slugged 47, but Ken Griffey hit 48.
Nevertheless, as Grieve said, no other player has matched Palmeiro's streak. Ruth hit 38 or more in seven successive seasons, Willie Mays, Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa in five each. Eddie Murray, who will be inducted into the Hall of Fame in July, didn't reach 38 once. 
Home run inflation can be cited as a factor that has helped Palmeiro, but not one of his contemporaries, including McGwire, Sosa and Barry Bonds, has matched his achievement. As for run poduction, baseball no longer tracks game-winning R.B.I., but Palmiero has done all right with R.B.I. generally. He has driven in more than 100 runs each of the last eight seasons, and ranked 25th on the career list with 1,597.
Frey does not begrudge Palmeiro his achievements. But he did mention one development in his and the Cubs' favor. "In 1989 we won our division," he said. "In Chicago, when you win your division, you can pretty much justify anything you do."

Sweep Is Not End of the World
Last season the Baltimore Orioles struggled for more than three months, from May 14 to Aug. 23, to get back to a .500 won-lost record. Five times they were a victory away from it but lost each time. Finally they beat Toronto on Aug. 23, making their record 63-63.
But that was the last day they stood at .500. They lost 32 of their last 36 games and finished 67-95. 
If that was woeful, how about the Orioles' act last week? They were swept in a three-game series by the Detroit Tigers, who had won only 4 of their first 29 games, had not won two in a row and had not defeated any team more than once.
"We didn't pitch well, at all," Manager Mike Hargrove said. 
Was the sweep embarrassing?
"You may be embarrassed by the way you play," he said. "But Detroit has a major league ball club. They have some talented people on the ball club. The Yankees they're not, but they have some talent."
The Tigers' sweep also raised that old .500 ghost, dropping the Orioles' record from 16-14 to 16-17. But the Orioles remained undaunted. They came back Friday, their next night of play, and took a doubleheader from Kansas City.

Mussina's Mark of Longevity
The Yankees right-hander Mike Mussina reached a career total of 2,500 innings pitched last week and was pleased with the milestone. Only nine active pitchers, all older than Mussina, have worked more innings, with John Burkett of Boston only a third of an inning ahead of him. 
Roger Clemens, Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine and Randy Johnson are the only active pitchers who have attained 3,000 innings, with the Yankees' Clemens the only one above 4,000. Another Mussina teammate, David Wells, is sixth on the list.
Mussina, however, has a considerable distance to go to make a dent on the career innings list. Twelve pitchers, for example, pitched more than twice the number of innings that Mussina has. For another example, Clemens, with more than 4,100 innings, is only 35th on the list. No. 1 is Cy Young with 7,354 2/3.

Time Does Not Tell Much
In their quest to speed up games, baseball officials should study the first game of the doubleheader Baltimore and Kansas City played Friday night. The Orioles and the Royals scored a total of 20 runs but needed only 2 hours 35 minutes to do it. 
Seven other games consumed less time Friday, but no more than nine runs were scored in any of those games. One game, Tampa Bay against Detroit, was only eight minutes shorter even though only two runs were scored. The Orioles and the Royals, however, quickly forgot how to play quickly. They scored nine runs in the second game of the doubleheader and took 2:46.
The second game was longer even though pitchers threw 276 pitches in the second game compared with 290 in the first, and the teams put 29 runners on base (seven on walks) in the second after having 39 reach base (eight on walks) in the first. Two pitching changes were made during an inning in the second game, compared with one in the first, but that difference was hardly the reason for playing 11 extra minutes while scoring 11 fewer runs.

HEADLINE: Harder Times, Even When the Living Is Easy; 
Summer Means Travel Cutbacks and Trading the Hotel Suite for a Tent

BYLINE:  By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
The never-ending winter has finally drooped to a close, and thoughts should be turning to the time of year when the stress and drudgery of home and office are left behind for the splurge of a summer holiday. Perhaps a week or two abroad, culminating at a restaurant with three Michelin stars? Eight languid weeks of sleep-away camp for the children?
 Maybe next year. With the economy still flat on its back and everything from taxes to rent to subway and bus fares climbing, this is shaping up as a year when even summer is being handed a pink slip. 
 No, children in Scarsdale won't spend the summer playing stickball, and don't expect to see fire hydrants gushing on the Upper East Side. 
But across the New York region, people seem to be scrimping on their summer vacations for the first time in years. They are planning shorter sojourns or scrapping them altogether. They are opting for car trips over air travel. And they are dropping hints with far-flung friends in the hope of avoiding the expense of hotels.
Many are rediscovering the romance (and bargain) of camping; New York State reports that campsite reservations are way up for the summer. The Catskills for $10 a night? Try finding that on priceline.com.
Some are sacrificing their own getaways so children can go to sleep-away camp, while others have crossed camp off the list completely. Lochearn Camp for Girls in Post Mills, Vt., which charges $3,950 for a four-week session, still has a number of open slots. "Usually, we're full by Nov. 1," said Betty Duncklee, the office manager.
In three dozen interviews, more than a third of the respondents said they were going to scale back on summer vacations this year, citing the anemic economy and their own precarious finances. Even those who have seen no drop in personal income said they were watching their spending.
In recent years, summer vacation for T. Sean Herbert, a producer at CBS News, meant a cruise to Nova Scotia and trips to Los Angeles and Florida. Before their first child was born, in 1997, he and his wife, Taryn Grimes-Herbert, went to Ireland for three weeks. "We take big vacations," he said. 
But this summer, despite a secure job, Mr. Herbert will spend July at home in Wyckoff, N.J., tackling home-improvement projects "without paying someone else to do it." He and his wife will make one foray up to Maine, as they do every summer for a family reunion. But instead of spending a week or two at the hotel, they will go for only four days.
Mr. Herbert called his approach a "pre-emptive strike."
"We really are trying to be cost-conscious at every level," he said. "I don't care how much money you have in the bank. There's no reason to waste it when everything is in flux and uncertain." 
Some parents whose older children are accustomed to going to sleep-away camp are canceling their own vacations. Denise and Dean Kupfer of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., are typical. Ordinarily, they sneak off to Florida or California after packing their daughters off to camp. 
This year, they are staying put. "Times have changed, and I'm the first to admit it," said Mrs. Kupfer, who works for a company that makes high-end cabinets. Last year, her husband closed his ailing sportswear factory in the South Bronx, a family business that had spanned three generations, and is now looking for a new profession, she said. Their daughters, Amanda, 11, and Samantha, 14, will still have their camp experience. But Samantha, who is bound for a snowboarding camp in Oregon, will go for only three weeks this year, compared with eight last summer. 
"Where I live, 90 percent of the kids go away, and they would be home alone," said Mrs. Kupfer, shopping at the Westchester mall in White Plains. "It's worth the sacrifice."
Some families may eliminate their summer vacations altogether. Amy Levine-Kennedy, a freelance writer, knows it is summer when she finally gets to poke her toes in the pristine sands of Cape Cod. This year she and her husband, Kostya Kennedy, and their daughter, Sonya, will instead plant their feet on the bottom of their swim club pool on Long Island Sound.
For the past four summers, the family rented a house for a week in Wellfleet, a picturesque village. But they have not signed a lease this time. Ms. Levine-Kennedy lost her job last year when her company, a health-care publisher, folded. And the couple just bought a new house in Larchmont and are expecting a baby any minute. (She is due today.)
"It's the one thing you can decide not to do," she said of summer vacation. "We contemplated not joining our pool for the summer, because that's pretty expensive, too. But if you don't do the pool, that affects your entire summer."
Of course, there are those who are not tweaking their plans a bit and, yes, even a few who are raising the ante. Patrick Daly, who does voice-overs for television and radio, said he and his family were headed to the Netherlands for two weeks in June, in addition to their annual trip to a working farm in New Hampshire.
But Mr. Daly, a resident of the Upper West Side of Manhattan, said the extra trip would not be a financial drain. They got a great deal on the air fare, he said, and they plan to stay with friends. "Since 9/11, we have looked at what's really important to us: whether we're enjoying our lives or not," he said. "You don't want to look back and say, 'Gee, I wish I had gone to Holland.' "
Lydia Sigelakis, a mother on the Upper West Side, said her family would also make a point of staying with friends and relatives when they go to Washington and Vermont this summer. "We're not going to travel anywhere that we have to spend money," she said. "My husband's not getting raises anymore, and we've had to dip into his retirement fund."
A number of people who typically fly to their vacation destinations said they planned to stay on the ground this year. Some cited the emergence of SARS; others blamed terrorism. But for many, the bottom line was, well, the bottom line. 
Harry and Rita Corradi of New Milford, Conn., will most likely take a series of day trips to Massachusetts. In recent summers, the couple, who are retired, traveled to Bermuda and St. Thomas. "It's the uncertainty of the stock market -- the fear factor," Mr. Corradi said.
Travel agents say plane reservations are off sharply this spring, but they caution that it is hard to tease out the exact reasons. Raymond Peter Kane, president of Pisa Brothers Travel Service in Manhattan, said the firm's air travel business was down 35 percent from two years ago. "It might be the economy, but there's no way to tell until the war and the SARS thing is out of the way," Mr. Kane said.
The trend toward a low-key, close-to-home summer is making this a banner year for New York State's campgrounds. From the Adirondacks to the Finger Lakes, campsites and cabins are being snapped up. The 270 sites at Letchworth State Park in Castile, about 45 miles south of Rochester, are mostly booked for weekends in July and August.
With cabins starting at $115 a week and campsites running $10 to $16 a night, a week under the stars costs less than dinner for two at a better Manhattan restaurant. Reservations edged up modestly in recent years, but this year they spiked. Through late April, New York State, with 14,608 campsites and 744 cabins, had taken reservations for 76,359 camping stays, up from 66,585 at the same time last year.
By contrast, high-priced vacation rental properties in places like the Hamptons are gathering dust. This year, many more second-home owners have decided to rent their properties, and that has caused something of a glut, brokers say. "It's been a very grim rental season," said Elaine Stimmel, an associate broker at Dayton-Halstead Real Estate in East Hampton.
Even affluent families who are fortunate enough to own a second house in a sought-after resort area are taking a parsimonious approach to the months ahead. "The state of the economy is certainly scary to us as a family," said Allyson Felix of Irvington, N.Y., who has a house in Cape Cod.
This summer, only her children -- ages 3, 6 and 8 -- will get new summer wardrobes. (Ms. Felix will make do with what's in her closet.) Forget about carefree nights at breezy waterfront restaurants, she said. "We'll cook in."

LENGTH: 1632 words

HEADLINE: So What's Not to Like? 

BYLINE:  By DAVID WINZELBERG 

 BODY:
LONG ISLANDERS are most concerned about jobs and traffic congestion, but they're happier with where and how they live than residents of New York City or its other suburban regions, according to a poll of Long Islanders that its organizers say is the most comprehensive ever conducted.
 The poll, commissioned by the Rauch Foundation, a Garden City-based philanthropic group, explored the perceptions of 1,387 Long Island residents about their quality of life and issues of concern. For comparison, 600 residents of New York City, 400 in its northern suburbs, and 300 in suburban New Jersey were also sampled, and Long Islanders appeared to be the group most pleased with life in their community. 
 While 67 percent of those polled in New Jersey and an equal percentage in the northern suburbs (including Orange, Rockland, Westchester and Fairfield counties) rated their quality of life as good or excellent, 74 percent of Long Islanders rated their quality of life the same way.
Long Islanders had a more pronounced sense of regional identity than the other groups surveyed, with 86 percent of Long Islanders saying they identified very or fairly strongly with their region. The equivalent figure for New York City residents was only 77 percent. 
Long Island also was the only region of the four sampled where a majority of respondents said that, generally speaking, most people can be trusted. 
But the goal of the Rauch survey, the first of three it plans to conduct, was not to help the Island blow its own horn but to identify community concerns and help foster regional thinking to address them. "If we can put some good information out there, we could be a catalyst for all the other civic groups to solve the problems we face," said Nancy Douzinas, foundation president. 
Edward Blakely, dean of the Milano Institute at the New School University in Manhattan, and a consultant on the Rauch poll, said no previous polling efforts covered quality-of-life policy issues on Long Island in such depth.
Respondents to the telephone survey, conducted in December and January and released in mid-April, identified jobs as the biggest problem facing all of New York's suburban regions. But more Long Islanders cited traffic than crime as a problem, reversing the ranking in the city and the other suburbs.
The most serious environmental issue for all three suburban regions was uncontrolled development, although suburban residents also appear to be happy with their parks and beaches, according to poll results. At least 75 percent of Long Islanders rated their police protection, sanitation and public schools good or excellent. But most Long Islanders called their public transportation fair to poor, because it doesn't go where they are headed.
The poll results were welcomed by Mitchell Pally, a vice president for government affairs for the Long Island Association. "Surveying Long Islanders, having town meetings helps us identify the problems and understand the ramifications of the issues," Mr. Pally said. "It could be very valuable."
Mr. Pally said he was not surprised that jobs were mentioned most often given the stagnant state of the economy. But he also pointed out that the poll results showed that people are staying here longer. "Most people who have moved to Long Island find it's not only a great place to live, but a great place to stay and retire in," he said.
Neal Lewis, executive director for the Long Island Neighborhood Network, said the poll would help to bring important concerns to the forefront, and indicated a change in the public's attitudes. "There is a growing agreement on what the priority issues are on Long Island," Mr. Lewis said. "Years ago, you couldn't bring up affordable housing, no politician would touch it. Now even business leaders are talking about it."
According to the survey, only 5 percent of Long Islanders said housing was the biggest problem facing their community, but 92 percent said "housing for working people" was fairly or very important. The affordability issue, though not labeled specifically, is a thread found throughout the responses, said Eric Alexander, director of Vision Long Island. "Jobs, the economy, and housing are all tied together with affordability," he said.
The median rent for housing on Long Island ($964 in Nassau and $945 in Suffolk) is the highest of any of the counties within and around New York City, according to foundation statistics. One out of three renters on the Island, and one out of four homeowners, spend more than 35 percent of their household income for a place to live.
Mr. Alexander said he was not surprised that uncontrolled development made the top of the environmental complaint list. "People don't mind certain kinds of development within our communities," he said. "But when they see new homes taking up a farm field, those become emotional images."
Mr. Alexander, whose group promotes a re-emphasis on village downtowns as shopping and cultural centers, also suggested that some Long Island respondents took a decidedly rose-colored view of where they live. He scoffed at the survey's finding that 84 percent of Long Islanders agreed that they had a walkable and bikeable community. "That is not matched with our reality," he said.
Craig Charney of Charney Research Institute in Manhattan, which conducted the poll, said the discrepancy could have come from a misunderstanding of the question or the way it was asked. He defended the general methodology, saying the sampling of Long Islanders closely matched the area's demographics from 2000 census figures.
But some contend that doesn't include everyone in the community. In his job as a public safety supervisor for the town of Huntington, John Ramirez said the biggest community problem where he works is immigration, which was cited by only 2 percent of respondents to the Rauch survey. 
"They are not counting correctly," he said. "It's not accurate. I know what's there."
The documented Hispanic population is growing faster than any other group on Long Island, increasing almost 80 percent from the 1990 census to the 2000 census.
While 72 percent of Long Islanders polled said there was racial diversity in their communities, Long Island is still 76 percent white, and has fewer minorities than the New Jersey or northern suburbs.
The poll found that 69 percent of Long Islanders said race relations in their community were good or excellent. Surprisingly, black and Hispanic Long Islanders were slightly more likely to have a favorable impression of local race relations. But at the same time, lower-income blacks were the only group on the Island to rank police brutality as one of the three biggest local problems. 
Some people were surprised by what wasn't mentioned in the poll. "I'm surprised that taxes were not considered one of the major problems," said Jeff Lipman, 49, a dentist from Huntington. (He did not participate in the poll; Charney Research did not identify respondents willing to grant followup interviews.) 
Mr. Charney said that although some respondents might have complained about taxes, a perennial Long Island lament, the question was never asked directly. But he suggested that later surveys in the Rauch Foundation series were addressing the issue, saying, "I have seen more recent polling that asks about problems facing government where taxes and budgets came out very high." 
The tax issue shows up in other ways, however. Although Long Island respondents said education ranked sixth on the local problem list, after the economy, traffic, crime, sprawl and housing, Beverly Wayne, 49, from Huntington, said education was the most important issue because "the biggest problem is finding a way to meet the needs of all the students with the limited resources available."
The poll showed that 86 percent of Long Islanders belong to some kind of organization, like churches, neighborhood associations or labor unions, and 96 percent said a strong sense of community was fairly or very important. But almost none of those questioned said they worked as volunteers and very few were active in civic groups.
"People are not involved enough in what's going on in their community," said Steven Landis, 56, of Hampton Bays. "They live in ignorant bliss." Mr. Landis said the "threat of the casino being built in the next couple of weeks" was the biggest problem in his neighborhood, an allusion to plans by the Shinnecock Indians to build a gambling hall on tribal lands just west of the Shinnecock Canal.
Another example of a tendency among Long Islanders to be disconnected from their surroundings was the 21 percent who said they didn't know about the condition of their waterfront. "Many people here aren't aware of the water, which is ironic because we are the largest island contiguous to the U.S. mainland," said Jay Tanski, a marine environmentalist with the New York Sea Grant program at Stony Brook University. Some of the ignorance has to do with lack of access, Mr. Tanski said, since a lot of Long Island waterfront, especially on the North Shore, is private. 
Mr. Tanski agreed with the 54 percent of Long Island respondents who rated their waterfront good or excellent. "Given the level of development in this area, the quality of the waterfront is very high," he said, adding that upland sources of pollution were the newest focus in maintaining a pristine shoreline.
The next Rauch poll, currently underway, focuses on children and families. The third is to address the economy. The three polls and an accompanying demographic study cost about $350,000, Ms. Douzinas said.
The Rauch Foundation was founded by Louis and Philip Rauch in 1961. The two brothers made their fortunes in the auto parts business in Brooklyn. Now the foundation helps fund civic, family and environmental causes throughout the Island.

HEADLINE: BRIEFINGS: COMMERCE; 
JOB LOSSES PREDICTED

BYLINE:  By Karen DeMasters 

 BODY:
 New Jersey will lose 13,500 jobs in five years because of increases last year in corporate business taxes, according to a Rutgers University study conducted for the Center for Policy Research of New Jersey. 
Most of the jobs will be lost this year and next, said Gregg Edwards, president of the research center and former Republican executive director of the state Senate. The tax increases are expected to bring in $1 billion a year to the state treasury. But Mr. Edwards said that, coming amid a slow economy, they mean that New Jersey lost businesses to other states and some businesses canceled plans for expansion. Karen DeMasters

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
GOODE, WILLIAM JOSIAH

 BODY:
 GOODE-William Josiah. The former Franklin H. Giddings Professor of Sociology at Columbia University, and former President of the American Sociological Association, died unexpectedly on May 4, 2003. The author of 20 books and over 80 articles on a wide range of topics, ranging from "Religion Among the Primitives" (1951) to "World Changes in Divorce Patterns" (1993), he was an Emeritus Professor of Sociology at Stanford University at the time of his death. William J. Goode was best known for his pioneering cross-cultural analysis of marriage and divorce. Drawing on his knowledge of nine languages, his pathbreaking monograph World Revolution and Family Patterns (The Free Press, 1963) analyzed data from over 50 countries to reveal the critical impact of family systems on what was previously assumed to be purely economic forces. Born in Houston TX in 1917, and encouraged by his high school debating coach Lyndon B. Johnson, he attended Rice Institute and the University of Texas, Austin. He served in World War II as a radarman on an attack transport ship in the Pacific. He joined the Columbia University faculty in 1950 where he taught for 27 years (1950-1977). In 1977 he became a Professor of Sociology at Stanford University, and in 1986 he joined the Sociology Department at Harvard University. He was a distinguished quest lecturer in China for the Chinese Academy of Science in 1986, and a Visiting Professor at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem in 1992. Known as Si to his friends, he was often referred to as a "Renaissance man" excelling in a wide range of activities including painting, sculpting, sailing, mycology, tennis, and birding. 
In the past 5 years he won several tennis trophies and published an article on "bird watching with your ears." He is survived by his wife, Lenore J. Weitzman, Robinson Professor of Sociology and Law at George Mason University; three children, Erich Goode, Visiting Professor of Criminology and Criminal Justice at the University of Maryland and an Emeritus Professor of Sociology at the State University of New York at Stonybrook, Barbara Baldwin, Women's Health coordinator for the Washington DC Department of Heath; and Andrew Josiah Goode, an architect in Shingle Springs, CA; and a sister Rosalie Grizzle of Magnolia, TX. His family is planning a ceremony with military honors at the Columbarium of Arlington National Cemetery (date to be announced.) They would welcome contributions to the William J. Goode international fellowship which is being established in his honor by the American Sociological Ass'n in Washington, DC.

HEADLINE: Unexpected Joys of a Workplace Seen the Second Time Around 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOEPPEL 

 BODY:
AFTER six years at the same company, Scott Breckenridge, 28, decided it was time for a change. He says he felt that he had gone as far as he could as a consultant at the New York information technology business Kraft, Kennedy & Lesser, so in spring 2000, he jumped at an offer from an Internet start-up called Hostcentric for a job with the fancy-sounding title of vice president for provisioning.
 Last May, Hostcentric laid him off as part of a reduction of its New York staff. 
 On March 31, Kraft Kennedy hired him back.
There has come to be a name for people like Mr. Breckenridge: boomerang employees. These are workers who grow restless at a job they have been doing for years, or even decades, and set out for greener pastures, only to become disenchanted with their new career, or to have the industry disappear out from under them. 
So, they go back home.
It is an increasingly common phenomenon, workplace experts say, as attitudes of both employers and employees have adapted to the ups and downs of the economy over the last decade. Companies, realizing that worker loyalty has all but vanished, are more willing to rehire people they know to be honest and competent, no longer considering them turncoats. Likewise, ambitious employees who once might have regarded a move back to their old place of employment as a step down in their careers are today more likely to take whatever they can get.
"The landscape has changed quite a bit; many of the old rules no longer apply," said S. Joanne Murray, director of the Center for Work and Service at Wellesley College and a management consultant. "I advise my clients to always keep strong, positive relationships with their former employers. It's quite common for people to go back."
Mr. Breckenridge says his return to Kraft Kennedy has gone smoothly. In addition to his previous responsibilities as a consultant who set up information systems for law firms, he is now also in charge of training new employees. He says he has spoken with his bosses about a future promotion to management.
There is good reason for the favorable treatment he has received. When he left Kraft Kennedy, he was determined not to burn bridges, and so he stayed in touch with his old managers and colleagues. He even played in a band with a former officemate.
He knew he would have a good shot at getting a job with Kraft Kennedy again, but when he was laid off by Hostcentric, he was hesitant about going back unless he could gain more responsibility than he had in the past. After some negotiating, he got it.
Joyce L. Gioia, a management consultant and president of the Herman Group in Greensboro, N.C., says she believes that boomerang employees will become even more common as linear career paths give way to what she calls hopscotch patterns. She thinks employers are coming to understand that returning employees like Mr. Breckenridge possess an important set of qualifications: a proven track record; new skills acquired since leaving; and familiarity with the company and its culture.
Plus, Ms. Gioia says, these employees usually have a new appreciation of the workplace they once left. "Employees leave because they think the grass is greener elsewhere," she said. "But what they discover is often crabgrass or even grass that's infected with chiggers."
As companies learn to value reconnecting with former employees, some have begun referring to them as company alumni to foster a sense of collegiality. Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, has even created the position of Americas alumni relations leader to establish a communications network for former employees -- at least partly in hope of luring some of them back.
Madge Nimocks, who was named the alumni relations leader at the company two years ago, says that from March 2002 to March 2003, Ernst & Young filled 96 management positions -- more than a forth of the total openings -- with boomerang employees. Last summer, the company created a Web site for alumni that allows users to view job listings in and out of the organization and provides access to career counseling and mentoring, Ms. Nimocks said. She said thatabout 15,000 alumni have registered.
Ms. Nimocks acknowledged that some in the company considered it unwise to provide resources that would make it easier for current employees to leave. But ultimately, management supported the site. 
"There's a recognition that people are going to come into the firm and they're going to leave the firm," she said. "While in the past, this might have been perceived as abandoning ship, now, it's, 'Stay in touch, down the road we might need you or you might need us.' It's a change of corporate culture that we want to embed in our employees."
SelectMinds, a company that specializes in building and maintaining Web-based alumni networks for corporations like Ernst & Young, Bank One and Accenture, promotes these networks as sound business moves. The New York law firm of Schulte, Roth & Zabel has its own network of alumni and organizes reunions about every 18 months.
Ms. Murray, the management consultant, while agreeing that returning to a former employer can often pay dividends, also warns of potential difficulties. If, for example, it is a move of last resort by someone who never really liked his old workplace but is desperate for a paycheck, she says, it can breed resentment on both sides.
"Going back for the wrong reasons can be poisonous," she said. "There's nothing worse than feeling stuck."
On the other hand, being thrust back into old terrain can come as a pleasant surprise. One New York-based technology executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he had mixed feelings when the division he worked for at J. P. Morgan Chase was transferred to I.B.M. in a seven-year, $5 billion outsourcing deal. The executive began his career with I.B.M. more than a decade ago, then left when it was struggling and now finds himself back as it has managed to right itself.
"I've boomeranged by default; we were sold into slavery," the executive said. "On the bright side, I.B.M., which was a dinosaur when I left, is now one of the best tech companies around. There's a lot of opportunity. They're not treating me as anything less of a corporate citizen."
More typical is the case of Robert Goode, 48, who returned to the Glazier Group of restaurants in New York in March as a catering sales manager 14 years after he left the company in frustration over what he viewed as too much competition among sales managers for too little business.
He went on to a series of corporate catering jobs in Lower Manhattan, including five years at the Windows on the World restaurant. After it was destroyed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, he got a job in Westchester County but returned to Glazier because he wanted to be in Lower Manhattan.
"Early in my career I was eaten up and spit out," Mr. Goode said. "I didn't have the client base then that I have now. My confidence level is much higher. The organization has a greater understanding of me and my reputation in the marketplace."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Scott Breckenridge, 28, is an example of a boomerang employee, someone who returns to a company he once left. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)
